												This game has a LOT of issues. Seeing as it's in the sale and there will be a lot of people considering buying it, I feel like I should outline the issues. TL;DR and specs at the bottom.- Performance, it varies from person to person but personally I have a medium/high-end gaming rig and still get stuttering and frame drops. I get smoother framerates on games with more graphic fedelity. On consoles it's the same story, constant frame rate drops.- There's a memory leak issue that is yet to be fixed. Instead of fixing the issue, the devs just raised the minimum RAM requirement from 8GB to 16GB and added a message for every time you boot up the game telling you that you have insufficient memory. Apparently getting more RAM actually fixes a lot of performance issues with the game, go figure.- The car handling in this game is so, so, bad. People says that Just Cause 2's handling was bad, but that game is a shining light of glory compared to JC3's habdling. And then just wait until you try a motorbike. The turning is horrid, it feels like you have no control sometimes. You hold down the button or move the stick to turn and there's a delay of about 1 second until your bike actually starts turning.  It's so easy to make them spin out and / or flip. Again, when the devs were questioned about this, they literally said "We think it's fine!" (can't find the link to the tweet but I'm sure it's out there).- There's no native way to change the FOV. There's mods that let you do so but then when you do change it a whole bunch of glitches appear, like terrain not rendering, animations ending, etc. I usually wouldn't mind, but the default FOV is so low to begin with, try driving a car, it's right up in your face and you can barely see past it. - Missions are creative until you realise that a lot of them are the same being repeated multiple times. Story is boring, I ended up ignoring it and just ♥♥♥♥ing around. Plus, at least for me, destroying bases got boring after a while because there's so god damn many. Just Cause 2 did the whole "Chaos" thing better. When you destroyed military vehicles, killed personnel, destroyed bases, etc. you would gain Chaos and once you reached a certain point you would unlock new items and missions. This worked great because you would end up unlocking things just by ♥♥♥♥ing around. Just Cause 3 however makes you liberate towns and bases, which are mostly just the same thing over and over again. Destroy these buildings, shut down this surveillance system, open this door, free these prisoners, kill there people. Over and over. It's very repetitive. As for Chaos? It's just a meanless stat. - The rebel drop system is stupid. In JC2  you earned money from missions and then used it to buy things from the black market, and you could also be picked up and quick-travelled to another province. In JC3 you have to collect flares from rebel bases, and then use those to call in a rebel drop. You have limited flares, but that's ok because you can just get whatever you want for free whenever you want. Right? Wrong, because there's ♥♥♥♥ing WAIT TIMERS. You sometimes have to wait up to 20 minutes before you can drop in a plane again. It's one of the most anti-fun things a developer can do and is often paired with micro transactions that let you reduce the wait, but JC3 doesn't even HAVE microtransactions so the decision makes no sense.Those are my main issues, but while I'm at it:- There's no minimap. Why is there no minimap. You can pause the game and look at the map from there to find things buy that's no reason not to have a mini map.- There's no sprint button. It makes Rico feel really slow in combat because you can't make him run any faster. The devs said that they want you to "use Rico's other movement skills" or whatever but JC2's sprint button was super useful.- Devs said they wanted to support modders but every patch completely broke most mod. I think there's still some mods that haven't been updated to the latest versions of the game.- Speaking of patches, there hasn't been one in months. You know what the latest patch was? DLC release. No big fixes. These devs charged us heaps of money for lackluster DLC and the worst part is I was idiotic enough to buy the first one. I'll give them the fact that have a booster on my wingsuit is cool but maybe they could use the extra time spent on DLC fixing the huge bugs in the game? Wait, that doesn't earn them money. Whoops, lol- WHY DID THEY RE-INVENT THE WHEEL AND BIND LEFT CTRL TO BACK. WHY NOT JUST USE ESC. YOU KNOW, LIKE EVERY OTHER PROGRAM AND GAME EVER PROGRAMMED LIKE EVER. WHY. TL;DR: Is this game fun? Hell yeah, I have like 70 hours on it. Is it worth full price? ♥♥♥♥ no. Buy Just Cause 2 in the next sale for like $3 and then play it for three years until Just Cause 3 is a similar price. Just Cause 3 could have been great given another year of development. But it's just gonna forever be that game that could have been ♥♥♥♥ing awesome but instead blowed and probably killed the entire franchise. Good job, Avalanche. Next time give the game to a competent development team.Rant over. Can you tell I'm still salty about a nearly 1 year old release?SPECS:i5-4460, 3.2 GHzGTX 970, 3.5GB VRAM (heh)8GB RAMaka way above recommended requirementsEDIT 25 NOV:This review got way more popular than I expected, so I thought I would fix a couple of things I said:1. The developers didn't actually bump the minimum amount of ram to 16GB. I thought they did, but I guess I remembered wrong. However, if you don't have at least 16GB of RAM, you still get a pop-up when you start the game telling you that your RAM is insufficient.2. I guess I was wrong to call my rig high-end, I've changed that to medium/high-end. While it's true that my i5 processor and 8GB RAM (the RAM particularly leading to the memory leak issue) aren't as good as an i7 or 16GB RAM, my gpu, a GTX 970, was one of the best cards you could get when this game released. Additionally, unlike what it seems like some people argue, i7's don't really make as much difference in games as they might think.I've noticed that the recommended CPU is actually an i7, but I feel like this further shows the performance issues with the game as you shouldn't need an i7 to run a game like this. Take, for example, GTA; a game that is arguably nicer looking and the recommended processor is an i5.EDIT 15 DEC:Looks like the game is on sale again, so a lot more people are reading the reviews. Try to be nice in the comments, it's christmas yo.

												Okay, so, I know I'm going to get a lot of dislikes for this review from people who disagree, but I want to help others decide on buying this game and I honestly don't want a rage review here. These are my personal experiences and opinions. If you so choose to get the game, either invest in the console variant, hearing it is more stable, or if this is not your thing, buy the game but use the Steam refund policy to test out how the game runs for you.Let's talk pros and cons, this is my first review here so I hope this will do.*pros* Amazing wingsuit. It's a great addition and I find myself missing it when going into Just Cause 2 now. (also: First DLC (Air DLC) Brings it to live even further) You're basically an Spiderman Ironman mixture. Awesome  The grappling hook got a massive update, plays differently, but it's just overall much fun and easy to learn. Massive improvements to the game world, it feels less empty. The scenery is awesome, and has a lot of variation.  The story, while everyone thinks it's bad, is actually good. It's an improvement, I'm stating this as a pro. Liberating is fun, but let's face it, we're all here for the bases. (At least, I am) I love the SciFi approach in this. While not everyone agrees and I'm likely one of the few, that like SciFi. And, it doesn't feel cluttered here to a point it becomes only SciFi.  The weapons, while some of them are overpowered, are fairly well balanced. But some should actually be buffed.  The graphics looked fairly great on my end, I could play the game at HIGH or sometimes ultra (given the game allowed me and the patch doesn't ruin it) at ultra 58 fps. (More on this in the cons and further down) There is a massive amount of eastern eggs, great! Explosions. EVERYWHERE. The user interface is great, very great even. I still miss my minimap at times, but I can get used to it.  Basic things like controls, achievements are great! Well done! The AI is.. silly. It's actually fun.Okay so, after reading this you probably ask yourself: But hey, then the game is fun, and good, why don't you recommend it?Well, here is where the cons come in.*cons* Performance  I know I said I said the gamed looked nice on my end, but this was in the past. Updates have serverely broken the game down on my end. The performance got worse over time. Just like my Samsung phone with touchwizz, but that's for another time. What. The. ****. You let me pre order, a YEAR before hand, (This was my choice I'm aware, but I was really hyped, read further) then charge me 10% off with the garbage "Weaponized Vehicle Pack" Which, quite honestly I tried and it is really bad. Then, right after release, you give it out to buy, which is fair enough, but THEN, it goes on sale where the entire game with the dlc is actually cheaper than when I bought it. Now, normally I wouldn't really care too much, but when the rest of the cons are there as well, you star to question yourself what life is. The bugs.. THE BUGS...... The glitches.... I can't express how annoyed I am. But let's keep my frustration as much away as possible. The water dissapears often, completely, causing me to restart the game. There's MASSIVE memmory leaks, which were there before hand as well. You get under the map ever single time you try to mess with the trains (which are.. actually fairly entertaining, for a while) and the amounts of crashes is over the top.  The games forced online. wow, this isn't my first point here, because I liked it for a while. But, when I told the game to go to OFFLINE MODE. I clearly want it to be offline. Now, why the bloody shish does it then, right when I open the map, go online???. My internet connection is really good, but even then, you manage to need to reconnect every single time Iopen the rebel drop and map, or switch to the menu? Why? The DLC/season pass/all other stuff. Now, I'm not minding DLC too much, and given the past of this games developers with Just Cause 2, I had high hopes in it being great. And, I was right, the air DLC blew my mind. Then, they released the land DLC and I was.. less happy but it was still yay, and then there was the last DLC.. The sea dlc.. And I lost my entire happyness and gave up on this game. Now, the DLC itself isn't bad, but you've charged me 25 Euros for a 3 weapons, 2 vehicles (of which one is a boat and I dont see myself in a boat in this game, sorry) and 3 new places to visit of which 2 are fun and 1 (the oversized oil rig) is just ... why. Mod support. (Hey, Floofershy, why do you even dare to call that a bad thing?) Well, simply because.. there's none.Modding tools aren't needed to give mod support, don't worry about that, Homeworld Remastered was an example of that at the start. But I'll be goofed, you break your so called mod support with every single update, which progressively also broke my game. Aside fom that, your so called mod support has caused the modding community to actually die out. If modding this game is your thing, don't go buy this. Multiplayer. I'm not a multiplayer game player and I don't play it all to often, but, given the price tag (Which is actually now below what I payed for it, well done), you would expect at least multiplayer to give a turn into the game. Now, I don't say this for myself, I say this for the many many people around me. You guys rely on us, the community to bring it to your game in the form of a mod. But, instead of helping, you break the mod support in a way there is not only no progress, there's just no fun in waiting for it anymore. Repettive. The whole game feels this way, from the stories to the bases to .. everything. They did well giving another look to each base for sure but it does not feel as rewarding and fun as it was in Just Cause 2.  THE DEVS..... Telling me to fix the game by adding more ram, upgrading my PC/Laptop isn't a solution. I'm not the only one with these issues, as a DEV you should actually fix them and not let me pay more money to get this game working.Now, about the latest Sea DLC:-----start sea dlc-----I was ignoring all hate on the DLC I read prior to playing it but I have to confirm it's severely lacking.. This has to be one of the worst things I payed for in a long time, the game entirely. I'm a long time Just Cause fan, and bough just cause 2 here on steam to support the developers. And then, bought Just Cause 3 including the season pass, knowing it would be good, I even pre ordered the game a year before hand.. I .. honestly think this is the worst decision I've made. It's a fun game, dont' get me wrong, it's just not something I can play as long and as much as Just Cause 2. And the bugs are serverely game breaking to a degree of being unplayable. And instead of fixing them, they bring out DLCs that.. litterally lack anything I hoped to have from the game.-----end Sea DLC----- I think I explained everything in my cons and pros, as far as I find needed. The game is great, for a while. Then it gets boring..Decide for yourself if the pros outweigh the cons, but for me I've lost faith.Note, it seems that performance varies per platform. so console performance is from what I hear better than the performance I'm personally experiencing. Any of you can decide upon that, if you wish to pick this up asap, I would reccommend looking into the console version.Will I stop playing because of this? No, of course not. Likely I get bored and start playing again, hoping the game doesn't die on me or becomes unplayable. But in no way do I hate the game to a degree I despise it. That said, I do think the cons I stated are serverely big given this being a Triple A game.

												**WARNING** Do NOT buy unless you have a PC with a minimum of 16gb RAM. Even the developers advise you this in their official statement:- ''It has been confirmed that the biggest perpetrator for all of the issues people are experiencing in JC3 is due to its memory leaking. The best "fix" you can possibly make is to upgrade to 16GB or more of system RAM''. This means the listed minimum specs of 8gb are incorrect and the devs know it. Just Cause 3 suffers some of the worst memory leakage ever seen in a video game which cripples performance on rigs that comfortably surpass the basic minimum requirements. The optimisation is utterly abysmal and the developers seem more content on farming out DLC instead of fixing the catastrophic problems that make the game unplayable for many. This has been going on since launch in December 2015 and it is clear these problems will never be fixed. The devs simply cannot be bothered and as echoed in their statement; only an upgrade to 16gb RAM will suffice.  I'd go as far as to say this is a far worse situation than Batman: Arkham Knight and if this was a bigger brand; it would've received just as much ridicule. It doesn't matter if you have an i7 with a GTX 970+ and run the game on low - the memory leaks persist if you don't meet the increased RAM requirements and you will be lumbered with constant stuttering throughout. The fact the developers published a statement that contradicts the specs on the store page but then wont ammend them, just shows a despicable level of dishonesty and disregard towards oblivious prospective customers. They've risked their reputation, community fury, and a huge amount of potential refunds for the sake of selling a game advertised on specifications that don't work to any satisfactory standard for a significant amount of users. When a developer has to sacrifce their integrity to appease the publishers for the sake of grabbing cash by any means possible; it further dents the credibility of the already dwindling AAA market but this situation is on a level of disgust you'd rarely see even from the usual modern day culprits of this industry. Avoid at all costs unless you have 16gb of RAM and enjoy extremely mundane and repetitive gameplay. The developers couldn't give a toss about their game and nor should you.

Not as bad as you may expectSeems JC3 has received some pretty much hate since release.But I just lowered my expectations, and took a leap of faith.No regrets yet.It's the most silly, mindless, unrealistic ride of destryoing things since "Red Faction: Guerilla" (which tried to be serious though).JustCause is to the FarCry-Series like "Saints Row" is to "GTA": It's its mad brother. You can't trust him, he's abusing drugs and hits on your wife (or hubby). But he's more fun at parties than accountant-brother.The good (what to love): It's just "Just Cause 2" but more of the lovely stuff, even less serious, and even more hillarious physics The new tethering-stuff is an awesome pool of crazy, twisted and even horribly mean fun The wingsuit/parasuit enable for nearly endless flying Blowing up stuff has never been so much fun. Place C4 at the right spots, detonate them, watch all come down.  Realism? Not in the slightest! Leaderboards with a very nice feature: Race the ghost of your friends (or others). You select someone else from the leaderboards, and start the challenge. It's like multiplayer but solo :-) Mods (though not officially and only a handful right now, but some more will surely come) Performs pretty well and still looks decent for 2015 (yes I know, seems I'm lucky here) Better (but still not perfect) car-handling Beautiful italian setting Large open-world fun Collectibles like audiotapes, cards, vintage-parts. Enough to keep collectors busy Want to punish your minions? Tether to feet and tower. Retract. Laugh evilish. If there would be any limb separation you could quarter them with 4 tethers :-)The mediocre (not good, not bad, but no show-stopper either): Challenges. You don't HAVE to do them, but if you want all those gadgets and goodies and abilities, you'll sadly have to do them. And win them if possible (5-Star). Funny for the first time but some tend to be frustratingly hard. At least for me :-) After around 15hrs I only had one bug where the car I was driving suddenly dissapeared. Been more funny than annoying though. Beside this I only had very minor glitches with the tethering. Stupid, unskippable lengthy intro. (Edit: Thanks to mods, you now can...) Animals are pathetic. One wrong look and they drop dead. Walked into a deer. Deer dropped dead. Walked into a goat. Goat dropped dead. The ugly (what to hate, may kill the fun): Enemies spawn. Sometimes you kill two guards on the 5m² top of a damn high tower, turn around and there they are again. HORRIBLE, ANNOYING and a real showstopper Season-pass-bullcrap again. Please stop this pandemic brainfart Killing EVERYONE does not matter at all. Kill a dozen rebels in front of other rebels and they still yell "Yay! Rico! Make me babies! Prego!" Though I can't complain at all, according to the mixed reviews and general critics, it has many bugs, flaws and runs crappy on AMD Can't remap controller but keyboard. Half-done jobRecommended?If you liked JC1+2 and enjoy the mindless, phsyics-defying destruction-rampage: YES.If you already found JC2 to be too silly, unbelievable and unrealistic: HELL NO!It may not be perfect, it may have some problems, but beside the spawning-horror and the more-or-less forced challenges it's a damn funny and mindless ride!I cannot understand the "mixed" ratings except they're mostly because of the technical problems it may have (which I cannot judge). It's a worthy successor in abeautiful environment and it "upped" Rico from a guy with a grappling-hook to basically Ironman without the suit. It sometimes even felt like "Prototype" :-)As far as I am in this game: Not one crash, no annoying glitches, no game-breaking bugs. Had expected much worse!According to other reviews, you may wait for at least the first patch if you own any AMD-Hardware though :(

My take after 5 hours... I would both recommend and also discourage people to buy/not buy this, but I could only chose one option so please read on to see why!Performance - Does it run?After an initial drama with getting it to run at my native resolution - the game crashed every time I switched res and eventually I had to change it in the config file to get it to load - on my machine yes it does, and very very well.. However I'm lucky enough to have just upgraded to the following:i7 6700k @ Stock 4.0GHzAsus Maximus VIII Hero Mobo16GB G.Skill Ripjaws V 3000MHzMSI GTX 980Ti Gaming 6GNow I realise this is at the upper end of the hardware scale, and if you're in a position similar to me you can expect to be able to play at a minimum of 100fps (average of ~130) on 1080p with every setting on maximum, so I'm expecting 80-90 on 1440p when I get a new monitor in a couple of weeks (will update with the actual figure).The game seems to be a bit of a memory hog and while playing it my system uses about 8.2GB with just the game and a few google chrome tabs open, so this could potentially be an issue for people with less.As others have commented, the initial game loading times are quite slow (using an SSD), however once the map is loaded in, the missions etc load very quickly.Gameplay / FeelI've only played 5 hours but this is my 2c so far..The game looks jaw dropping and if I'm honest is half the reason I bought it, to see what my new system was capable of. I messed around a bit with lowering some of the graphic settings and with a lot of them the quality of the game doesn't decrease too much and you can gain a few fps by doing this, so I wouldn't be worried about how its going to look if you play at medium etc - it will still be incredibly pretty.After getting over the initial oooooo this is pretty thoughts, the actual game itself is fun in the respect of being able to mindlessly blow things up and fly about like a super-spider-bat-man kind of combo thing (it's bizarre!) It's fun jumping in a tank and blowing up a petrol station, or in a helicopter that has infinite spammable missiles, or planting mines on a bridge, then causing a pile up before blowing the whole thing up etc etc...Regarding the campaign / story, well to me (admittedly a Just Cause noob) the premise is a bit thin.. a dictator has gone a bit mental and therefore we need to crush him and his minions by taking over towns, then more towns, and a few more, and then a couple more after that.. you get the point. These towns are all just clones of one another and there are only so many "fun and creative" ways to shoot, blow up, or pull down yet another identical red billboard or telegraph pole in order to take over the 100000th one.I know already I wont be able to stomach completing the story as its simply just too damn repetitive. The side missions to upgrade your perks etc are sort of fun, but really not challenging enough to take seriously.The cars in the game are HORRENDOUS to control, by either a keyboard or a controller, they just plain suck. The heli's are much more fun, but a bit too EZ-MODE. I've had the most fun just cruising around on my parachute & wingsuit (which is a good laugh when you get the hang of it) and getting up to random mischief - such as slingshotting people with the tether device combined with booster bombs and seeing how far someone can fly without a parachute! Again though, this will only last so long, and after it wears thin I probably wont log back in as it just doesn't have enough pull to keep me interested.Conclusion+If you have some decent PC hardware (that doesn't include an AMD gpu (sorry guys!)) then the game *should* run ok, and hopefully even better after a patch. If this is the case for you, you will be treated to a super pretty game with a MASSIVE world to go mental in.+If you are the type of person to roam about on GTA and just randomly cause chaos you will no doubt love this game, as nothing will compare to the madness you can create.+If you're the type of person who enjoys a good story with engaging, challenging and varied game play too, you should probably pass at least until its in a steam sale, as you will soon find it tedious and frustratingly repetitive for the £40 price tag!I hope this has helped at least someone! Please comment below if you found this useful, or alternatively crap! Please feel free to let me know what I could have done to improve this, if anything!Thumbs up if you like and down if you don't!Cheers.

												Steam really needs a one thumb up and one thumb down option. I love Just Cause, so I was really excited about this release. Especially when they talked about improving the driving physics and other tweaks to make gameplay better. JC has one of the most fun open world environments, and is a great destructive sandbox. Unfortunately in my small gameplay time so far, there are a lot of cons.1) You still move like you have one leg. As you turn you spin, in a 360degree fashion, not just simply turn. This makes for awkward movement when you need to face and activate an object.2)Driving is still a negative. While DRASTICALLY improved over JC2, there is still a lot of work to be done here. Instead of fast paced and moving on ice as in JC2, JC3 is a slowed down drive on sticky tarmac. Turning is slow at first then exagerated to the left or right very quickly. 3)Controller/keyboard controls. I have to use both. I use the controller for general movement and the mouse for aiming/shooting. Neither one performs exceptionally well on their own so I've found a compromise and use both. 4)The map is not very informative. Also, in doing the missions, you have to be close to your objectives if they are in white. (Things you need to do to control settlements.) Yellow indicators appear from any location and are easy to find your destination. Once you are there however, they become white, and are things you need to explode or activate to complete your mission, and can be a pain to find.5)Enemies seem to pop in out of thin air sometimes. Not from a great distance mind you one time it happened from 10 feet away. 6)The leaderboard function. Both a Pro and a Con here. Con is anytime logging in it takes a bit longer with this feature active, popups can get annoying. 7)It seems AMD users are having problems with some texture popin and textures failing to load. AMD users need to stay away until a patch is introduced for you guys.  I did not experience this with my Nvidia EVGA 980Ti SC ACX+Square_Jason has been active reguarding this problem http://steamcommunity.com/app/225540/discussions/0/485623406959941125/Pros1)Graphics. The game looks very nice. 2)Performance. Im running a single 980Ti in 4k@60 fps with absolutely no frame drops. It's a very solid performer. 3)The leaderboard function. Both a Pro and a Con, it's fun seeing what your friends do in game and trying to beat them. 4)Destruction. Very fun to blow things up still and very many creative ways of doing it, from grappling, grapple tether, guns, bombs, cars, planes, etc. 5)Open world sandbox. This is the bread and butter of Just Cause, and with 1000km2 of open world to explore it delivers again.SIDENOTE: The airstrikes the enemy calls on you are REALLY ANNOYING...they have amazing accuracy on moving targets. Use this to your advantage! Stand next to a target, let them bomb missiles on their own equipment! Rinse and repeat to take out settlements without firing a single rocket.SPECS: i7 4930k, 32g ram, EVGA 980Ti SC ACX+ , ASUS 4k monitor @60 fpsThese will get updated as I continue playing, and while there are a ton of negatives it is still JC and a very fun game to play. Despite all of these negatives it's a very fun game. 7/10 so far.

Posted: December 13, 2016
												This is a good game. Is it a great game? Probably, but there are a few issues.There are a lot of improvements from Just Cause 2. You're still raising hell on an island nation, but this time the ridiculous characters feel like they are entirely on purpose, and this time it's a lot prettier. There are a lot less collectibles and settlements this time around, but frankly, that's a good thing. Just Cause 2 had way, way too much to do, and not all of it was satisfying. Sometimes you could spend twenty minutes on a military base looking for that one last thing to destroy, the one insignificant little generator that you missed, that one crate that you didn't pick up. This time, once you start a settlement, you're told what you have to do to liberate it. Destroy the speakerboxes, destroy the propaganda vans, raid the police station and free the prisoners. It's fairly entertaining, the first few times, but after that it becomes somewhat monotonous.It is pleasant to watch a province side with you after liberating everything within it. That was something that was missing in Just Cause 2, you can easily and visibly track your progress across the nation this time around, much like you could in the original Just Cause.Then you have the various challenges, wherein you earn 1-5 gears based on your performance. Mostly optional, and although gears unlock upgrades for your gear and vehicles, you don't need to get five gears on every single challenge to unlock everything. Which is good, because some of the challenges require you to perform absolutely perfectly. I was stuck on one of the wingsuit challenges for a good forty-five minutes. Thankfully, I could have just given up and gone on to other things, as I had already unlocked all of the available upgrades, but I was determined and bored.So the challenges are hit and miss. Some of them are actually fun, and add a neat element to the game. The races are generally pretty decent, except for the occasional moments of flipping your car. The destruction challenges are fun, but most of them can be cheesed by using something else. For example, the boat challenges can be difficult because most of the boats are hot garbage. But when a helicopter spawns on the outskirts of the challenge map, complete with rocket launchers? Not even remotely difficult. For the most part, I enjoyed the wingsuit challenges. You follow along the predetermined route and hit the circles, aiming for the middle for maximum points. And most of them, you don't have to be perfect to get five gears. Some of them are obnoxious, some of them are downright peaceful.The story in the game? Meh. I mean, don't get me wrong. I'm happy that they tried. They didn't take themselves seriously this time around. I mean, not that they ever did. But in the first two games, it still bordered on sense. Things got weird on occasion, like the ninjas with the submachine guns, but they only popped up a few times in the entire game. This time, they have a cast of wacky characters, all of whom are entertaining, none of whom get any closure whatsoever when the story ends. And that's my only real problem with the story. I like that it's silly, I enjoyed when the main character punched a computer screen and said "♥♥♥♥ you, missile", that was just a good time. But when the game ends with no fanfare, it feels underwhelming. It is underwhelming. I completed every single challenge with max gears, I liberated every single settlement, I did all the DLC, and the game just...sort of peters out.On the note of DLC, it's fantastic. I picked up the Just Cause 3 XL pack on sale for twenty-five bucks. It includes three DLC storylines, each with new areas to liberate and a game-changing, almost game-breaking item being the reward for completing it. A gun that calls lightning down from the sky. When powered up with the gear upgrades, it is ridiculously overpowered. You can bring down a military base with the power of the gods. I ended up shelving that one because it was too much, and I wanted to have a touch of challenge. If I was going in for a second playthrough, which I will inevitably do, then heck yes I am going to use that to clear things out. It has some difficulties hitting aerial targets, as you have to make sure you're aimed right at them, and keep the cursor directly on them until the lightning comes down, or else it will blast off into the distance, destroying innocent trees. But for groundbound targets, it's pure death. This DLC pack also introduces the only boat in this game that is not a steaming pile of floating crap. The Loochador is a boat with a ridiculous amount of nitro boosting, high speeds and steering, and a barrage of rockets to destroy your foes.The one piece of DLC gear that I DID use, and use a lot, was the jetpack. Holy crap, is that thing awesome. Just Cause 2 introduced the infinite parachute that defies physics, gravity, mass, just about everything that you hold true in the universe. But who cares, it makes the game more fun. This time around you have the infinite parachute again (which is even jokingly mentioned in the game), and the wingsuit. But the wingsuit is only useful when you're high up in the air. You move faster, but you can't get much air back. Until you get the jetpack. Now you can propel yourself through the skies. Who needs a vehicle when you have a highly unstable bavarium jetpack strapped to your back? Add to that, the fact that it has both a machine gun AND a missile launcher, both with infinite ammo and a reasonable cooldown time. Plus you can upgrade it via a series of challenges similar to the wingsuit ones, but designed with the boost in mind, making them much more difficult and interesting. At any rate, this piece of gear made my journey across Medici a lot quicker. The only downside of it is that SAM sites now detect you as an enemy aircraft, and will fire missiles at you if you get too close. Which you can avoid, if your timing is good. But it does make life a little more difficult, which is probably a good balance for a device so utterly useful.The last piece of DLC equipment is a mech suit. Gun arm for the pew pews, and gravity arm for picking things up, throwing them, or just doing a devastating gravity punch and eliminating everything in front of you. Once you have the gear upgrades, which are, like the rest of the DLC gear upgrades, gained by completing specific DLC challenges, then your mech suit is a force of mechanical doom. You can pluck helicopters out of the sky, throw them at other helicopters, gravity punch entire waves of enemy forces, and pick out enemies with upsetting accuracy with the autogun mech. The other mech is dumb and I hate it. Also, once you've completed everything and have it unlocked, if you don't want to drive it you can call in a rebel in a mech suit to wreck♥♥♥♥♥♥FOR you.Each of these pieces of DLC gear are gamebreaking in their own way, which is kind of perfect for a game like this. They're not needed, which means the base game is completely unprepared for them. For my first run through the game, I only used the jetpack, and held off on the weapons it has, because they felt like I was cheating. For later runs, I have no doubt in my mind that I will use these mech suits and lightning guns to destroy my enemies so fast that the good general won't know what hit him until he has a lightning mech knocking down his door like the friggin' Koolaid Man.I like this game. I enjoyed it a lot. I had a huge grin plastered on my face from the moment I started the intro cutscene. I would definitely recommend picking it up, especially when it's on sale. For twenty-five bucks, it took me fifty hours to get through on my first playthrough. Definitely worth the price. My only issues with this game are the ending, which didn't wrap things up as much as I would like, and the fact that it crashed a few times. But it has a generous autosave feature, so I never lost more than a few minutes of mayhem.

												I was so excited for this game.  I loved Just Cause 2 and knew for sure its sequel was going to be a hit.I was very wrong.The pros:Updated physics and graphics, better grapple/parachute mechanics, the wingsuit, awesome explosions and destruction.  An overall beautiful game that has so much potential.The cons:-Performance is very poor especially for those on PC (unless you have certain Nvidia cards I believe).  The game was created as a console game and was not ported over very well.-Memory Leaks.-Gameplay is constantly interrupted when there's a disconnect with the server.-Devs don't appear to actively support or fix these issues.-No minimap-Car and motorcycle handling is absolutely atrocious.  They seem to have been made for just console controllers and wheels, then directly ported to PC.  The lag is huge between pressing a button to turn on the keyboard and the vehicle actually turning, to the point that you'll fall off cliffs, hit buildings, and spin out of control because there's no sensible way to make the vehicles do what you want.  It's not just a learning curve, or something to get used to - it's a design flaw, because the only way to control a vehicle is to possess Jedi abilities to see what's coming before it happens.  Only then will you have time to press the key and keep it pressed long enough for the car to respond in time.  I can't even get in vehicles in JC3.  I'm belaboring this point because vehicle chases and combat were such a huge part of JC2, and they're completely ruined by these shoddy mechanics that the devs still stand by.  They should, at the very least, give the option to revert to JC2 mechanics.The list goes on.  It hurts me to say, but don't buy it.

												I wrote a negative review a while ago for this game, saying that the game "used to work but no longer does." However, I got it to work, and it ended up being fantastic. The problem was my controller. If you have the controller plugged in when you boot up the game, you get about 1 frame per second. If you plug in your controller after you start playing, it works. Now that I have played it, I can review it correctly.The game is good.The campaign is much higher quality than that of Just Cause 2, and it is much longer. I did enjoy the characters, cutscenes, stories, ideas, etc. and there was even some good humor thrown in. The campaign seems to take itself more seriously than the one in Just Cause 2, which I thought was a great choice on Avalanche's part. For veteran Just Cause players, there are some "easter eggs." For example, in Just Cause 3, there is a big island in the top-right corner that replicates the one (in the same spot) in Just Cause 2 (although this one has no inhabitants). Just Cause 3's capital, Regno, has a sister city in Just Cause 2 called Bandar Baru Nipah, which I thought was awesome. In addition, just like Just Cause 2, a funny radio announcer will talk about the base that you just blew up to try to calm the dictator's people. Rico also has some throwback quotes.The destruction in this game is total. I was constantly in awe of both how much infrastructure Avalanche had created and how much I could destroy. Blowing stuff up in this game is amazing, especially with the unlimited C4 supply. You can be extremely creative, and there is a ton to do. There are functioning trains that you can ride up and down the mountains, and you can get cargo planes and put cars inside, then fly them high above the country. The wingsuit is very fun to play with and get better at, and the grappling system has been much improved.The music is fantastic, and rivals Just Cause 2's soundtrack. The country, Medici, is similar to Panau in that it is extremely diverse. There are beaches, forests, snow-covered mountains, and sea. This makes traveling around the world seem much less deja-vu than it could have been. The towns and cities are beautiful as well, making you feel like you truly are in Italy. However, I believe that Just Cause 2 has the better world; there are more cities, more easter eggs, and less of the "filler" land in Just Cause 3.Overall, as a huge fan of Just Cause 2, I feel satisfied with Just Cause 3. The expreience has been amazing, and I think I will continue to play in this beautiful sandbox. Just make sure to unplug your xbox controller until you start to play!

OverviewI’ve played about 45 hours of Just Cause 3. In that time, I’ve done 54% of the challenges, liberated all provinces, found all collectibles and beaten the game.It has had its ups and downs, but overall, the game works. Yes, it stutters. Yes, it’s beyond poorly optimized, but it’s still a fun, if overly repetitive, game.I played this on an i7-4790k with 8GB of RAM and a GTX 980 Ti. After about two hours, the game would get stuttery, and the audio would stutter as well. Simple solution for me (not guaranteed to work) was to alt+tab out of the game, tab back in, and it worked fine for another couple of hours. Only twice did I have to quit out of the game and restart it to clear any stutter issues.That said, if you’re still interested in the game in its current state (as of this review), continue on. If not, perhaps come back to the game after a patch or two and decide if it is worth it for you to buy then.ProsJust plain fun to blow things up constantlyBig open worldLots to do (races, frenzies, wingsuiting, etc.)Opportunity to create unique situations with physics and the upgrades available to youFairly lengthy, will take you a bit to finishThe world looks very good on max settingsMusic and sound effects, for the most partLots of collectibles which reward unique vehicles or weaponsConsStory is as bland as it can get, and been done countless times before; same goes for the dialoguePoorly optimized; beefy systems will stutterRepetitive; not much variety to the bases or towns aside from new things being added (early bases may not have monitoring systems while later ones will, for example)Main story and upgrades become gated behind the challenges, which make them necessary as opposed to optionalCharacter models are bland, and enemies all look alike (regular soldier looks like every other, armored one looks like every other armored soldier, etc.)SummaryThe game is not without its issues. You could have a powerful system and still succumb to sub-30FPS without horrendous audio and visual stuttering. On the flip side, you could have a mid-range system and not have many issues at all.Taken without its issues, Just Cause 3 is still a fun game. It’s best played in chunks, because the repetition will tire you if you were to play it for hours straight.Finally, I recommend Just Cause 3 because when it works, it’s pure fun. There’s something to be said for arcadey games in today’s world, when a heavy focus is on strategy and realism, and with its insane explosions and aerial traversing, Just Cause 3 has arcadey in spades.

												Summary: If you liked Just Cause 2, you will most likely enjoy Just Cause 3. If you're anything like me, you'll enjoy spending hours mindlessly dicking around with explosions, physics and stunts and this game gives you ample means to do so.My impression is good so far, I'm having a lot of fun and I'm looking forward to spending lots of time messing around. If you buy this game expecting a deep and introspective work of art, look elsewhere. If you buy it and are looking for a fun game to experiment with and show your friends, this is the game for you.Pros:- Beautiful graphics and map design (love the vivid colors, lush landscapes and the sea is gorgeous.)- Very fun gameplay (explosions, flying, and killing, oh my)- Lots to work towards if you are a completionist- Non-linear so you can progress past the missions or ignore them altogether after a point- Lots of Easter Eggs- Civilian cars can be captured and then ordered via black market supply drops- Lots of models of cars, planes, tanks, and weapons to use- Super corny voice-acting (JC staple)- Sound effects are high quality- Visual effects are stunning- The new Wingsuit navigates really smoothly and is very fun once you get the hang of itCons:- Occasional bugs (nothing game-breaking for me as of yet, but I've had to restart a few missions due to bugged objectives)- Physics are wonky as hell (can be a pro in some cases, it's more geared towards fun than realism but mostly proves clunky and strange)- Driving has some of the worst physics I've come across in any game (motorcycles are nearly impossible to drive)- Moving rico around can be a hassle and interacting with vehicles or items can be a pain- Not much depth story or character wise, but this is to be expected- Always online can prove to be a nuisance if your connection is spotty (constant reconnection attempts)All in all I am happy with my purchase and would recommend it to anyone considering it who knows what they are in for in a Just Cause game. I will update this review as I put in more hours.Specs:- i7-4790k- 16 gb ram- Nvidia 980- Windows 8- 7200 rpm HD- 1440p monitorPerformance:- Stable fps around 40-50 on very high settings @ 1440p- Load times take around 10-20 seconds per cut scene (not ideal but it isn't on my ssd so it's expected)Thanks for reading!

												I see a lot of mixed reviews on the store page, but I had a blast so far with my first (7 hour) run in this game.  The game runs smooth at 60fps for me and I did not encounter memory leaks nor noticable bugs like many reviewers have mentioned. I did see a few AI glitches when they are at pop-in render range, but other than that it's all solid and smooth. It is basically an upgraded more polished Just Cause 2 game with a few new gimmicks and features. I liked the K/M controls layout more in JC2, but I got used to the new controls pretty quick. The only thing I don't like with the controls is that your character can't fall off a roof anymore. If you want to get of a rooftop then you have to jump, you can't just walk of it. Overall the game is an improvement to JC2, but there are some design changes in JC3 that I do not like that much. Specially that they have now locked away upgrades behind 'challenges' is a bit annoying. The old way of upgrading by creating 'chaos' was a lot more fun and was not seperated from the game like these new challenge locations.  The graphics are nice too, it is more realistic themed (Italy) and the whole atmosphere looks more realistic than in JC2.  I definitely recommend this game, if you liked JC2 then JC3 is a nice addition to have in your library.

Posted: January 25, 2016
 Just Cause 3 is by far the best game in the Just Cause series, and an absolute must-have for open world fans. StoryIn the story of Just Cause 3, you play as Rico Rodriguez, some sort of Spanish Rambo. Rico's massive open world home Medici is suffering under the typical dictator, who is oppressing his people, and threatens the whole world with his bavarium weapon production. It's obvious that the CIA is looking to get in on that too. Only Rico is in the way.GameplayIn the struggles against the dictator you must support the rebels of Medici by freeing over 130 villages, cities, outposts, oil rigs, and military camps by wreaking havoc. In addition to that, you must deal with countless singleplayer missions, challenges as well as sidequests.For these tasks, you are provided with all sorts of weapons, vehicles, and gadgets. It's up to you whether you use a car, motorcycle, boat, plane, helicopter, parachute, wingsuit or your grappling hook for progression. The possibilities are endless.Sadly the leveling system of Rico is both limited and almost pointless, since he is already very good at everything, but still you can unlock "upgrade-mods" through completing challenges. These go all the way from target practice to racing.Pros:  Gigantic open world leaving the players their freedom of action. The story mode with 25 missions is done very well, and offers a variety of action. Lasting enjoyment in the gameplay thanks to the map's size, liberty of the player, the numerous singleplayer missions, Steam achievements, sidequests, 130 villages/camps, that are to be liberated, and tons of challenges. Phenomenal graphics, especially the explosions look amazing. Ideal handling with both controller and keyboard. You can bind all keys individually. Vertical movement. You can fly, drive, walk, swim or dive. Great! A great repertoire of cars, tanks, motorcycles, boats, helicopters and planes. Realistic sound effects. Funny radio hosts, and by now bug free.Neutral:  The released game was extremely buggy. Some AMD graphics cards didn't work, there were problems with processors and much more. By now all's fixed. The main character's supposed to be "cool", but his quotes are really just lame. There's barely any music in the game, but somehow it doesn't harm the gameplay, since there are radio hosts, evermore explosions and shootouts with amazing sound effects.Cons: Always online DRM isn't just annoying, because Steam often suffers from server issues. It also costs performance.No Steam cloudSadly no MultiplayerConclusion:Even if DRM is annoying, Just Cause 3 is a gigantic open world must-have game that mustn't be missing from any collection. This review was written as a valuation inside of its own genre.Total rating: 8,5/10If you liked this review or want to see more recommended games, be sure to follow our curator group: Follow Original Curator Group

Posted: September 5, 2016
												Unlike Just Cause 2, the predecessor to this game, which was a very good game, ran very well, and had few stability issues, Just Cause 3 is rife with stability issues. It's evident that the game was developed on one of the home consoles, and then ported to PC, and that port was a halfhearted attempt at best. Despite releasing patches that should have fixed memory leaks, Avalanche's go-to answer for stability issues is still "Upgrade your system to 16 GB ram." Despite the fact that the recommended (not minimum, but recommended for optimal performance) specs are 8 GB of memory. And even then, upgrading to 16 GB will only "prolong the period between crashes".They seem to want to release all sorts of paid DLC, but seem to have very little interest in making sure the base game runs well before doing so. Because of that, I cannot recommend this game. Despite being what could have been the strongest entry into the franchise, the developers decided to make a console game, and then port it to the PC with a minimum of testing, resulting in one of Rico's most disappointing outings.

												This game feels like a beta... besides the optimization problem that's been posted thousands of time, the game mechanics are barely improvement over JC2. If you want a TL;DR, skip to the end.Improvements over JC2:-AI is a bit better than in JC2. They attempt to hide and call for reinforcement when all of his friends were killed. AI also spawn tanks now so you actually have to be slightly more aware when tanks are around-explosion. This is a huge improvement over JC2, no question.-aircraft. Instead of having 2 similar combat planes in JC2 that had a machine gun and rocket, the air combat is a bit better because there's a more dedicated bomber for those who love to drop bomb, and a fighter craft that has guided missile that hit both air and ground.-more traffic. driving around make you realize Medicci is more populated than Panau-wingsuit, one of the selling point of this game-multiple grappler hook that you can force it to pull. now you can just cause helicopters to crash with a tether or 2-a few more guns/weapon than JC2, a bit more interesting choice for weapons than JC2, but that's mostly because of the 3 super weapon(airstrike, EMP, and mini nuke) that you can choose later on as you progress through the story.-doge mode(look up on youtube for this easter egg). "much 2nd amendment". LoLwhat this game did wrong:-no minimap. Like what was this development team thinking? Often you'd have to open up you map to see where nearby things are at, this is very painful. Also the lack of minimap made the AI a pain, which lead up to my next point:-AI spawn, is a PAIN in the butt. Basically when they removed the minimap, they made it so you cannot see where the military reinforcement is coming compare to JC2, thus 9/10 AI spawns tend to be not where you're looking, so often when you're fighting 10 guys and suddenly you realize you were shot behind. You turn around and see a combat jeep with 4 guys just spawn, despite that behind you is actually a friendly army base.-air combat. Yes I did mention air combat was an improvement over JC2, but that's because JC2 barely had any air combat(not including multiplayer mod). In this game, besides the main story, where the air combats are all scripted in the story, there is no aircraft AI for JC3. Getting your self to level 4/5 heat in a fighter or a bomber, and guess what? The game decide to spawn tanks for you to blow up. The game won't spawn fighter craft to engage you. So you can keep your dream for air to air combat till at least JC4(or unless someone can create a mod this).-DRIVING require fixing, especially for motocycle. You cannot control the motocycle with a keyboard at all, PERIOD. Even when you're driving straight, the tiniest bump will cause havok and make you lose control. Also applying the nitro booster on a motocycle and you're asking for a traffic accident.-challenges. Basically challenges are just tiny minigames, usually involved with time trial/explosion highscore... etc. However they're not particularly exciting to do, and often you need to retry, but the load time isn't particularly fast, which makes challenges some-what frustrating. Also challenges are pretty much manditory to do, because you need to do challenge to unlock gear mods(gear mods basically modifies certain mechanics, like giving you stronger grappling hook, more grenades to carry, giving nitro booster to rebel drop vehicles... etc), and to get maximum fun, you need those gear mods. Challenges should have been optional. Best get a mod to give you all the gears so you don't have to do them.-rebel drop. Basically rebel drop is the replacement to your JC2 equipment/vehicle request that Sheldon deliver to you, and they don't cost any credit(aka free, but this game don't have credit either). However 2 problems: rebel drop require you to first pick up a beacon, and second once you dropped your favourite vehicle/plane/boat, it goes on a LONG timer until you can drop that same vehicle again. Often your plane dropped somehow ends up 99% damaged and so not only you wasted a beacon, but your favourite plane is now on a long 30+minute cooldown. There is gear mod that remove the timer, but like I said, they're not really fun to unlock and it will take you quite awhile to unlock it.-always online. Yep steam DRM isn't enough, apparently you need to be online all the time to update the online leaderboard(that isn't even a global leaderboard). This "always online" not only can time-to-time kill your save file(if you didn't install your JC3 to the same hard drive as your windows O/S), drop your FPS, get spammed with people beating your record, and makes your loading longer. A temporary solution require you to put a firewall around your JC3.exe.TL;DR/summary:Anyways this game is a slight improvement over JC2, but it still has many problems to fix. I would not recommend this game at its current state. If you really want to play this game, then get it on 50% sale at least.Edit: I like to mention this is a soft negative as in this game can probably still fixed, but until it is done, I don't fully recommend this game unless its on a good sale(or fixed).

												TL;DR - I loved and sunk hundreds of hours into JC2 across PS3 and PC, and it's still better than JC3 for me at this point. That game oozed character and polish; this one completely lacks either.  Optimization issues aside, it's an "okay" action game; it's not a great Just Cause game.2015-12-11 UPDATE: A week and a half later and patches still haven't fixed the performance issues, but having twice the amount of recommended RAM apparently helps a ton for some people. I bumped up from 8GB to 16GB and get a pretty steady framerate and the stuttering is gone. That's on a system with a GTX 660Ti, which technically is under spec, yet I'm flying around the game at 60fps on High settings (I even got JC2 and JC3 running side by side, windowed, on the same machine, with playable framerates in both after adding the RAM).  Also, user-created mods are starting to emerge that fix annoyances like bypassing the stupidly long intro video and giving you access to more supply/vehicle drops to play around with.The frustration with the issues below was magnified by the performance issues.  Having mitigated the latter, and having sunk almost 40 hours into the game, I've started to find workarounds for the unsavory design changes from JC2 that aren't intuitive or particularly user-friendly.  You just get used to it, but that doesn't make it better.  Being essentially an enjoyable 'Wing Suit Simulator 2015' aside, the rest of the game still has plenty of moments where it feels like a Gobot when you asked for a Transformer.  However, if you never played JC2, you won't miss what you never had.I still think JC2 has more polish and replayability for me, but if/when they finally patch out the performance issues, I'm on the fence enough at this point that I might change my recommendation to more favorable.  Optimization issues aside, it's an "okay" action game; it's not a great Just Cause game.  But for now, don't drop $60 on something optimized this badly.ORIGINAL REVIEW:Pros:Wingsuit is pretty cool for a couple of hours, then it loses its novelty.Causing huge train wrecks is kinda fun.Prettiest fire and explosions I remember seeing in a game.Retracting tethers to rip things apart is enjoyable for a while.Equipment drops have been streamlined from JC2.Reprogramming SAM launchers to fire on enemy choppers is nice.The game tells you which objects still need to be destroyed or interacted with to capture a settlement or base, and the last few will even show up on the map if you're having trouble tracking them down.The soundtrack is good at times, especially while using the wing suit.Cons:You can't remap the X360 controls in a game in 2015.  Please.The FOV is too low and needs to be adjustable.You can't skip the annoyingly long intro; noticed that RAM usage ramps up while it's playing, but there's still a bunch of loading even after that.The always-online leaderboard stuff is amusing if you're into that, but it should be OPTIONAL.  The amount of stuttering and connection problems and gameplay interruptions it causes are inexcusable. Firewall the JC3 executable to turn that off for good without crippling Steam in offline mode.In JC2, you had a shoot button and an explosives button.  You still have that, except that selecting C4 now makes you put your gun away. If you bring it back out, you auto-switch back to grenades, which is especially problematic once you unlock Glass Grenades because it's really easy to blow yourself up if you're not paying close attention to the stupid auto-switching of explosives they introduced. Grenades should be on a different button than C4 OR using a gun should not switch back to grenades.On more than one occasion I have intentionally disabled some of the skills I had unlocked because they were getting me killed more than they were helping. What kind of skill system does that?Objective and incoming fire indicators are small and hard to see against the background. This is exacerbated by the removal of the minimap to tell where enemies were in relation to the player.Crouch, run, dive, and the melee grapple-whip attack are gone.The acceleration and handling for most vehicles are slow and laggy.  Makes many of the challenges a nightmare to bother with, and you need those to unlock arbitrary "upgrades" that would be standard features in other games.There's no way to just "drop" from wingsuiting like you can from parachuting. You unlock the wingsuit air brake later, but they hard-mapped it to the same button as release tether, something you want to use to gain speed while wingsuiting. It's fundamentally screwy.Random frame drops and game freezing (presumably while loading...something) just make the vehicle and wingsuit handling that much more of an issue.  My 120fps will plummet to 4fps for no apparent reason, whenever the game feels like it.Descriptions for challenges can be misleading. I did better on a Sniper Rifle Challenge by stealing a helicopter and blowing everything up rather than actually, ya know, using a sniper rifle and shooting the absent-yet-hinted-at red barrels.  The description implies there's an intended way to do some of them when in reality you can just sort of screw around until you find a better way.Load times for some challenges take longer than the challenges themselves. This makes retries really annoying.Everything feels so generic and soulless and half-hearted. The missions are lame and boring and the challenges are repetitive and uninspired.The prerelease game footage is borderline bull-shots.  So many people are having massive performance issues compared to that produced footage.The gunplay feels stale and boring. Bullet impacts don't feel significant, and enemies just sort of slump over.  Some even get back up unexpectedly.I still don't know how to tell how many beacons I have for supply drops without simply trying to initiate one.You can drop C4 while parachuting, but you can't throw it while standing on the ground.  You have to literally be touching whatever you want to use it on.  Also, you can't set it off if you're inside a vehicle.  What?Finding tapes and shrines and stuff isn't as interesting because (IMO) the detector for those seems less sensitive and responsive than the one in JC2. I've circled entire city blocks looking for one more bar of "you're getting warmer" to just see it sit at three bars.Capturing every civilian car isn't interesting because the car handling sucks and why would you want to capture an underpowered Honda Civic to summon it for a mission?I miss the different factions of JC2. I've only seen one in JC3 so far, and they have zero personality.There is so little story leading in that I don't even really care why I'm here. JC2 had you hunting down an arms dealer and rescuing a dork from a casino in high explosive fashion. In JC3, I guess I'm just here to overthrow a regime.The damage model feels inconsistent.  I can take sustained fire from a chopper and walk away with minor damage, but take a couple shots from some random grunts at the wrong time and it's insta-death.  Similarly, you can wingsuit into a brick wall at full speed and shake it off, but if you zipline into barbed wire, insta-death.There are so many moment-to-moment annoyances in the game that it makes me actively angry to play it. There's a good game buried in here somewhere, but big fans of the finer points of JC2 will have to suffer to find much fun here.Conclusion:The whole thing is just such a disappointment after a) How great JC2 was, and b) The pre-release footage looked amazing and refined and polished.  The final product is none of these things to me.  Some of the more glaring issues might be fixed in later patches, but I don't know that I care to wait around to find out.  Give it a year of patches and about an 80% price cut, then maybe reconsider it.

EDIT:Other users have pointed out in the review's comments that they could play the game without any issue with only 8GB RAM. By my assumption, only people running a Radeon GPU will have this problem while Nvidia users tend to be running the game smoothly. Of course, this could be wrong - the point is that this game's performance is a bit of a hit-or-miss so don't base your decision to purchase this game purely on this review. Instead, do a bit of research first to determine whether or not Just Cause 3 will run on your current system.Below is the original review I wrote before it was mentioned to me that the issue wasn't present for all users with 8GB of memory or less.- - -8GB OF RAM IS NOT ENOUGH.This is the first and last thing you should know about Just Cause 3. The optimization is the worse.Do you know why Just Cause 3 wasn't delayed? Because the optimization was so bad that the game had to be launched on the same year as the infamous Batman: Arkham Knight so that the optimization would seem comparably good.All jokes aside, how. the. ♥♥♥♥. do you screw up the optimization a sequel to one of my favorite game of all times (Just Cause 2) so ♥♥♥♥ing badly. How. Where did you go wrong, Avalanche? Just Cause 2 was amazing. Sleeping Dogs is considered one of the best open world games out there, and I recently finished playing Mad Max which has beat any of my expectations by a long shot, and hyped me for the release of Just Cause 3. All three of these games had excellent optimizing and great graphics. Then what happened for Just Cause 3? Who was in charge of optimization for Just Cause 3, if anyone?I know that the developers are constantly working on improving the performance and fix issues with the game, but so far these attempts haven't been very convincing at all, with updates after updates doing a whole lot of nothing as far as I can tell, and as I try to deal with the constant freezing, crashing and frame drops, the game is still, unfortunately, unplayable. Why? Because you WILL have memory issue if you have 8GB of RAM or less installed in you computer. You WILL have poor framerate, you WILL be forced to reduce the graphics (which really aren't that elaborated, let's be honest here, I can play most games some of which have better graphics, on highest settings without problem except for Just Cause 3 – don't get me wrong, the game is gorgeous, or it would be if it actually ran properly on medium graphics settings).Top three issues with the game---"Crashing – Lack of RAM"So far, I have not left the game on my own even once. The game will kill itself eventually, usually after around 0.5 to 1 hour of gameplay. Hooray for modern technology, insuring that quitting a game is never necessary for PC gamers around the world.---"Freezing – Lack of RAM"Again; apparently 8GB of RAM will not be enough, because as soon as you attempt to open the Steam overlay in-game, your game will freeze. Your desktop will freeze IF you manage to exit to desktop. Your computer will freeze. Your mouse cursor's speed will be reduced to 1FPS, and you will not be able to do anything at all, except force a shutdown of your entire system.Yes, I did try Ctrl+Alt+Del, and no. Even that didn't work, because my memory usage was at ~35% in use and 65% modified (or at least, if I can trust AMD System Monitor (which I do). That's what happens when you don't have any free memory.---"You have been disconnected... again"I can't explain that one, neither why it happens nor if it just happens to me, but I keep being disconnected from the servers and requested to re-attempt login. And no, I don't want to play offline. Why? Because the online part of the game is a feature of the game which I expect to function correctly. I shouldn't have to disable a feature because it just doesn't work. It should work.With that said...“Is the game good?” I hear you ask. Well, I honestly can't say. Is it good? I couldn't really get a chance to try it thoroughly due to the awful optimization. From what I've seen so far, it is an amazing game, or should I say, it could be an amazing game. However, unless you have a monster rig of a computer to play the game on, forget about this game ever running properly. Unless you have 16GB of RAM or more, forget about Just Cause 3, it won't run, you will have wasted you hard-earned money. Get Mad Max instead. Same developers team, godly optimization. It may not have parachutes, wingsuits, grappling hooks and machine guns, but at least it's playable.I really hate to give this game a bad review, but as I've already repeatedly mentioned in this review, the game is simply too poorly optimized, and until the developers fix it (which I doubt they will), I will most likely not change my review. Sorry Avalanche.PS: The game is fun though. If you have a very good computer, it's probably worth it.

												I absolutely loved playing this game.  The game is perhaps not as good as Just Cause 2, but free roaming the island and destroying everything you find is a ton of fun.  Unfortunately, Square Enix chose to take the low road and released this so-called AAA game in an unplayable condition.  Players are reporting varying amounts of success getting the game running, but one thing is certain: the game will crash on you eventually, and when that starts, you're very unlikely to be able to continue.  My game survived a glorious 12 hours of chaos and destruction.  Now it crashes within 10 minutes of startup.  That's not enough time to finish a mission, so I am completely unable to progress the game.The game has several game-crashing bugs that make the game unplayable. Most notably is memory leakage that causes the game to slowly fill up all your available RAM before it crashes your entire computer. There are several other issues that cause framerate stuttering, flickering graphics, and save file corruption. Square Enix is aware of these issues, and has been for a long time, but is doing nothing to fix them. In fact, the most recent patch they released actually caused more issues.  I submitted a support ticket and all they did was accuse my system of being at fault.  My system is way above the minimum specs for this game, so I know it is not my hardware.  (That, and the fact that thousands of other players are reporting the same problem should be a clear giveaway that it isn't a hardware issue!)

content:
Posted: January 1
												In terms of creativity this is a very successful sequel and a loving continuation of the Just Cause series. This game is totally gorgeous, fun and loaded with cool content. It’s just such a shame though, that there are some serious problems with the performance. The outstanding quality of the design work, makes it shocking, that it could have been released in such a poorly optimised state. As so much love and consideration seem to have gone into making it something special. However, it appears to be yet another example, of the economic side of things pushing the release date forward. Resulting in an incredible game with mediocre performance at best. The pricing and distribution of the DLC content also represents some shady business practises. Although again, from a design stand-point, this additional content is fantastic stuff.Following some tweaks which included making some changes in Windows 10. I managed to get it running, just well enough, to be able to enjoy myself. However I am still experiencing crashes, stuttering and poor framerate. I’m running it on a GTX 980, an AMD FX 8350 and 8 Gigs of RAM. Apparently it’s the RAM that’s the main problem, as there is a warning every time I start up the game, stating that my system memory is low. Typically however, my 8 Gigs of system RAM, is totally fine for gaming in 2016. Especially since I spent over 700 Euro to get a GTX 980 with 4 Gigs of VRAM. Basically, Just Cause 3 runs like♥♥♥♥♥♥and you’ll need a powerful rig to get it running even moderately well. I have read online that if you have 16 Gigs or more of system RAM, it helps a lot but that is not normal. I get how people are angry about the performance problems but this game still deserves a lot of praise.  I’m going to recommend it because it is an example of how amazing videogames can be in 2016. Even though, the corporate money making side of the industry, seem to be determined to ruin things with short term thinking. If you have a decent PC, you can probably still get it running well enough to appreciate how incredible it is.Edit: I got some feedback in the comments and it seems like some people might also get 'okay' performance, on low to medium end PC'S, with low settings. This seems to be a bit random though, so maybe you should do some research before you buy. I said in the comments below, that 'okay' performance for me would be something like 45-60 FPS with occasional crashes and stuttering. This shouldn't really be acceptable with my GTX 980 but I still think the game is worth playing. Anyway, just know that you are gonna be compromising on performance, one way or another. It also seems to be a bit more of a gamble when you are using a lower end rig.

content:
Posted: December 10, 2015
												The message from the devs alone that was released on the 2nd of December started out with "We received some great review scores". This translates itself to "We feel justified in what we did and we've, like, you know, made the greatest gaem evurr and gamers should just shut up"- loading times are awful even on SSDs- for a quite large player base, the game is simply unplayable due to the inefficiency and bad optimization- story is rather short. About 4 hours (with cutscenes) when you leave out the "chores" of having to liberate a certain amount of provinces. Cutscenes are fun, the missions themselves are boring- way too many challenges that are the exact opposite of chaos. Better yet, for 100% completion you need to do most of the 112 infuriating challenges twice, because you need upgrades to reach 5 gears. Hurray for repetitionI'll give them kudos for a) the beautiful world, which is often quite accurately resembling a mediterranean environment and b) the fact that collectibles and destruction objects are completable this time. In Just Cause 2, the amount of collectibles and destructables in villages/bases was just far too ridiculous.All in all, another AAA title released in a very sorry state, even if this isn't affecting all users (but a large portion of them). What do we learn? Business ethics in the gaming industry are still plummeting and a great part of that goes out to us gamers who time and time again spent money on darn pre-orders or day #1 releases for no reason. To clarify, I was gifted this game free of charge by a very, very kind person.Edit: (Dec 17th)In conclusion, it's a fun game. I kind of like it, enjoyed most of it, as I did with Just Cause 2 (over 50 hours there) What some people don't seem to get is that I simply won't give a thumbs up for pure mediocrety. Yeah the game's ok. But it's downright mediocre. And the poor release state, the excruciatingly annoying DRM and the fact that I'm expected to pay some 75€ for the complete experience - if I were such a customer - doesn't make me want to recommend this game. I will never support mediocrety and give it a thumbs up. And honestly, the reason gamers have put up with mediocrety for so long and have given their thumbs up to anything that was broken, uninnovative but well-marketed is one of the key reasons most AAA publishers are just declining in quality, support and simultaneously expect customers to spend more and more money.I can see some people disagree with me, but they're as entitled to do that as much as I am entitled to express my non-recommendation at this price point and state of the game.Get it for 15€ / $20. Then it's a good deal and worth a recommendation. Also, most bugs will probably be gone then, so it's an even better deal.As an AAA title asking me to invest 75 bucks? Nope. No. Never.

Posted: December 2, 2015
												I wish I could post a review with neither a thumb up nor a thumb down, because while it's cool and looks good, I still have a lot of gripes. There are some MAJOR problems that need to be addressed, but if not for them the game would be excellent and probably have a much higher average review rating. Since my experience with the crashes and problems that other users have been complaining about have been fairly rare, I'll be rating it positively, but considering how frequent they are among the playerbase in general I almost feel bad for doing so. -Pros-The explosions please my idiot monkey brainSome parts of the environment, such as walls, now crumble when explodedThe new grapple/wingsuit etc mechanics are niceThe game is very pretty, especially underwater (as long as you don't look too closely at anything, it's pretty jarring in cutscenes to see every thread on Rico's shirt while the fence he's leaning against is blurry and pixelated)-Neutral-Car handling is different than in JC2, but arguably not for the better- cars aren't slippery TNT rockets made of paper mache any more, but they're also much slower and their turning feels somewhat unresponsive until you're suddenly pulling a hard turn that almost flips you (or just does)I'm conflicted on Rico's new design for some reason. The change in his facial appearance, attitude, and way he talks- even though not changed on any fundamental level- feel like they've gone and replaced the original with a lookalike halfway through the film and expect us to not notice. Nothing meaningful, it's just a slight nag at the back of my mind during cutscenes that I just can't shake.-Cons- (starting from arguably the worst) People have been complaining about explosions crashing the game. This doesn't happen to me- instead, it crashes my entire PC every 10th time I throw a grenade. Even if nothing else is going on at the time.I have 2 GTX980s in SLI and even I can't run this game on Ultra at a smooth 60fps. Have to turn most of the post-processing things (motion blur, depth of field, bokeh, SSAO, etc) off-- and all of them at once, not just one or the other-- in order to jump from ~40fps to ~120. That's... not good optimization. EDIT: The game apparently doesn't even support SLI, hence the unexpectedly poor performance.The Online features can make it take AGES for the game to load at the start, in ADDITION to the annoyingly long intro video every time you playThere seem to be cutscenes every five seconds (at least at the beginning), and the directors have apparently never heard of changing camera angles without a complete fade to black between shots followed by a loading screen once the cutscene is actually overThe auto-snap on the grapple line is... annoying. It gets in the way and makes you frequently grab things you don't mean to.You don't have very fine control over your movement, turning around and around in order to get a context action to show up (get in car, press button, etc) is more frequent than I'd prefer.For a game all about explosions, they don't give you anywhere NEAR enough room to carry explosives.I'll update this review as I play more & depending on how frequently the developer updates the game. Hopefully the devs fix the game-breaking problems quickly so I won't feel so bad about leaving a positive review.
