content:
Posted: December 24, 2015
SummaryJust Cause 3 has all the gadgets and exploding objects necessary to be a fun game, but it's been made into a frustrating experience. All of the fun stuff is hidden behind tens of hours of completing infuriating challenges and liberating repetitive military bases and villages.ReviewJust Cause 3 lacks any enjoyment during the first 50 hours of gameplay in my experience. It is not worth paying for such frustration, especially at full price. It took me 50 hours to lift the limitations placed on the player at the beginning of the game.At the start of the game, I wanted to try exploding things in new ways, particularly with the new tethers, but they were disappointingly underpowered. The only way to improve tether strength and to get more than two of them was to liberate an ungodly amount of land. Eventually I unlocked the frustrating tether challenges. That took many boring hours. Although I now have fully upgraded tethers, I do not have the ability to enjoy them.Another way Just Cause 3 stifles enjoyment is the fact that the player never has time to set up crazy destruction. The player will be killed by Di Ravello's army before they are able to successfully set up some elaborate, insane way to explode a statue using a car, tethers, and rocket powered C4. The number of potential ways to explode things are brilliant, but the number of opportunities to are not.What really destroys the game's fun are challenges. They are how all gear mods are unlocked, from rocket powered C4 to multiple tethers. Gears are awarded based on the player's score, from one gear to five gears. The player needs a pretty high average score (3-4 out of 5) to unlock all gear mods in any category, such as car modifications.What I first search for in every challenge is a way to complete it ASAP with a better vehicle or weapon, but that's not always possible. Fortunately, most challenges don't take too long. Unfortunately, there are some that seem impossible to score highly on, even with all weapons and vehicles unlocked. The wingsuit and destruction challenges are particularly infuriating. The former requires the player to fly perfectly through the center of several rings, without missing more than 1-3 (depending on the course length). The latter sometimes limits the player to weapons that are not suited to blowing s#!& up in 90 seconds, such as sniper rifles. Being somewhat of a perfectionist, attempting to unlock all gears felt like a waste of my life. That's a horrible feeling to have in any video game, and especially Just Cause.The final modifications that can be unlocked for vehicles are the elimination of their cooldown timers, which is essential to have much of the fun in the game. Even the beloved wingsuit, an incredible method of transportation, has much of its functionality hidden behind challenges. The story and its individual missions are negligibly short, so it's up to the player to make their own fun with whatever Rico has. Without all of Rico's enhanced gadgetry, liberating the islands is a grind.One instance when I was actually having fun was actively discouraged by the game, another time when the game annoyingly told me what I can play with and when. I was trying to liberate a base before disabling its bavarium nukes, and unsurprisingly it was taking a long time. I was enjoying getting constantly blown up by nukes while trying to fight an army and destroy their infrastructure. Suddenly I was spawned kilometers away, at the nearest base I liberated, rather than by the fun nuke time. I flew back a couple times only to get nuked and transported a few kilometers away. I was livid.By the time I could use all of my gadgets and weapons with as much freedom as the game would offer, I was already 50 hours in. By that time, I had enough Just Cause 3. I did not feel like spending more time in its world with only a handful of different types of things to blow up that are arranged in many different ways. Maybe one day I will come back to this game and play it the way it should be, doing crazy nonsense.I thank whoever reads this review and recommend them to play Just Cause 2 instead. It's much cheaper and has most of the same explosions and non-physics, plus it never made me frustrated. I could mess around all day there, without making any progress in the game.

												So I've seen a lot of problems with people complaining the game is stuttering and crashing. Now me and 15 of my friends bought this game and not a single one of us has yet to have any problems. Two of us got the stuttering, but that's because they had their settings too high (they have quite a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ GPU) and once they changed those they had no problems either.If you try to max out your graphics with a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ GPU you shouldn't be complaining here and try some lower settings first!Now I heard some people who had good specs also got the stuttering and crashing and stuff. And you seem to see those a lot.My experience is that most reviews written are negative, since people can't really be bothered to write a positive review anymore because they're probably too busy playing this marvelous game. So there might seem to be a lot of these reviews, but that's just cause (pun intended) people mostly only write reviews when they have a complaint or are mad.Now if you have an AMD you should probably not buy the game yet, since it seems that activision hasn't done a lot of testing with these GPU's and the game is probably badly optimized because of it.What I'm trying to say is that the performance problems aren't nearly as big as they seem like. Posted: February 3, 2016
												I was looking forward to this game, not only for the game itself but because of the mod support they mentioned before launch.A month or so after launch and I am still very disappointed with the game for many reasons.It is optimised so bad. I'm running on a very good spec computer (see my profile for my full specs) and with lowered settings I average at about 50fps, but it's not consistent, it drops all the time or shoots up high which makes it really hard to play. Also putting on vsync (which is a must for me because of screen tear) causes the game to lock at a low fps if I dip under 60 which is really annoying.The game itself is just horrible to play. The car handling is awful and the physics system is completely broken, everything explodes for no reason and things will flip about and act completely unnaturally. If you tether two things together then pull them in they will flip into the air, and the effect is seemingly worsened if one car is on fire.The NPCs are useless. I don't even know how to describe how bad they are but just watch gameplay, you'll see what I mean.The voice acting I've experienced so far is not what I would expect from such a big title, it is very amateurish and doesn't sound like it's from a professional game, it's quite immersion breaking when the game itself looks so good.Load times are insane. I'm running the game on an SSD to try and speed it up, but it still takes ages to start for the first time and load into the level. It's really annoying that when I actually can be bothered to try and get my money out of the game and put up with all the problems it has to play for an hour or so, I have to sit in loading screens for ages to get there.Finally, there is no official mod support, at least that I've heard of, so I'm not sure what they were on about when they mentioned modding before launch. Were they just implying that they were making the files easy to crack into to modify? If that's the case then that isn't exactly official mod support, that's just making a game using common formats.Please fix this game, it has such potential but at the moment it's a mess. I would really not recommend buying until it's fixed, if it ever is.

content:

Basic InformationTitle: Just Cause 3Genres: Action & AdventureDeveloper: Avalanche Studios (Mac & Linux)Publishers: Square Enix (Mac & Linux)Release Date: The 1st of December, 2015General ImpressionJust Cause 3 is an amazing game with endless hours of fun, leaving you entertained after any length of play. The story is set in Medici, a fictional Mediterranean island where the main character, Rico Rodriguez was brought up. Rico left Medici due to a military coup and is back to save Medici from an evil dictator.  The game uses its amazing gameplay mechanics and awesome action to guide you through a long story which spans the whole map, letting you explore and enjoy the game’s massive open world map. The map represents the beautiful islands of the Mediterranean. The map consists of 3 regions, consisting of cliff side towns, vast open waters, vine fields, small tree filled islands, huge railways, mining outposts and huge mountains. The stunning scenery and vibrant colors gives Rico more of a personality because it shows the player where and how he was brought up, also giving Rico more of a reason to free Medici from its evil dictator. The story takes you through all the regions but it feels open ended, because of the amount of freedom you get. You lose track of the story and explore the open world yourself. But the story does try to keep you hooked to help you unlock special items and vehicles. The story is much better than the Just Cause 2 story because he has more of a purpose. But Just Cause 3 was never really about the story. It’s all about the destructive open world action and adventure. Just Cause 3 has still kept its amazing gameplay mechanics from Just Cause 3, improved on them and added new ones making the open world experience better than any other I have played. There is always new ways to destroy a certain military outpost and the amazing explosions become addicting. Just Cause 3 never gets boring because you can always find new ways to entertain yourself in the huge expansive map with challenges and competitive leader boards with friends, such as who can blow up the most objects in 10 seconds! The only issue with Just Cause 3 is that it lacks variety in its enemies, weapons, vehicles and bases. Destroying bases can sometimes become repetitive but the changes in scenery help to compensate for that. Only a few weapons, enemies and vehicles feel different from the others, but most weapons feel that same and fell like they have no purpose. However the DLCs compensate for this beautifully, the DLCs introduce new enemies, vehicles, weapons and bases with amazing diversity. The latest DLC the “Mech Land Assault Pack” add 3 mechs with freaking gravity guns where you can basically pick up anything with physics and throw it. Perfect for deforesting! Even though the DLCs cost £10 each they are worth it 100%. They will leave you with endless fun. Once you have finished the story you can re oppress military bases so you can attack them with your amazing mech! The game has a few performance issues and in some cases people can barely run the game but if you can bypass those issues it is a great game. The audio is nothing special and the music is nice. I especially like the weapon sounds and general sound effects. The user interface doesn’t obstruct the game but it isn’t anything special and there are a few things that I would change. Such as you can’t click escape to get out of the menus, instead you have to click “back” with your mouse. The graphics are great, that is if you can run the game at max settings. The textures look at bit washed out at lower settings, the water takes a massive hit when going form max to medium and in general the graphics could be better at lower settings but are not noticed when blowing up and tearing down military bases. The game engine, well let’s say, almost everything in the world is destructible and has great physics meaning you can flatten bases and rip apart vehicles with amazing explosion effects. Overall the game is absolutely stunning leaving your jaw dropped at all points in the game, the amazing gameplay keeps you wanting to come back and blow up everything again. It’s just more of the crazy and explosive sandbox game we love, but even better!Positive PointsHuge, expansive map with stunning sceneryAn engaging storyAmazing engine and physicsCrazy, fun and explosive gameplayUnbeatable game mechanicsGreat vehiclesLots of different types of environments and sceneryMinimal user interface, doesn’t obstruct gameplayControls are fine and easy to learnSteam achievements keep you hookedNeutral PointsThey should add a massive battle mode in free-play where the rebels fight against the dictator’s troops across the map such as seen in the storyNegative PointsThe DLCs are very expensiveSome bases become repetitive to liberatePerformance is not that good needs better optimizationGeneral Ratings Feature Rating Graphics 85/100 Atmosphere 90/100 Audio 76/100 Music 78/100 Gameplay 95/100 Story 82/100 DLC 93/100 Content Quality 79/100 Content Quantity 81/100 User Interface 76/100 Controls 75/100 Engines 91/100 Mechanics 98/100  Price Tag 75/100 Personal Rating 93/100

												Just Cause 2 set an impossibly high bar; I remember back in high school, talking with friends about how years from now, Just Cause 3 would be, like, the most fantastic game in existence if it ever happened. Imagine JC2 with even better hardware, and physics, and detail! Who'd ever need another game at that point?Alas, it wasn't to be. This isn't terrible, by any means, but I'm just kinda shocked I can't really recommend it. The gigantic map full of towns, cities, gas stations, and other such destructible things is now replaced with one that has lush, gorgeous greenery and beautiful coastlines... and huge empty spaces full of nothing. There's much, much less to destroy, which in a game expressly about destroying, is pretty damn sucky.The game's new additions are primarily locked behind boring, padding challenges that are best played by immediately ignoring their rules somehow. For instance, a challenge that sees you destroying an enemy harbor with a boat is most easily solved by setting up a ton of tethers and explosives, setting them all off at once, and, uh... never getting in or near the boat. Some of these are pretty fun, like the wingsuit challenges, but making them more mandatory than JC2's mostly decorative challenges made them far less enjoyable. It feels like busywork.The physics are phenomenal. This game is a magnificent tech demo. No pre-rendered destruction like before; every little piece crumbles apart. Water towers no longer simply burst in a convenient shower that masks the tower having its model replaced with a broken version, but now can be wrecked from any angle, including prying apart the individual supports until it topples to the ground. This level of detail is absolutely magnificent and I highly appreciate it. However, it feels like the game map is made so much more barren to compensate for this. When you're on a roll bringing down a base, you'll feel like an absolute badass like you should, and it takes skill and finesse now to pick everything apart during a firefight. Handily, those little extra pieces towards the end that are hard to find now get marked on your map.But despite so much of this feeling right, it feels like... I dunno. It feels like a tiny fraction of what Just Cause 2 was. Like it's not done. I have none of the DLC and that's really felt. You really aren't just, like, a tiny superhero in a massive playground of destruction. You're forced through a long degree of story missions, despite much of my praise for JC2 being, well, not bothering with that crap. Most of the game is story instead of sandbox, structured missions instead of whatever you want to do, exact sets of collectibles instead of general boosts. It's a game design step in the complete wrong direction from its magnificent predecessor.(And this is personal opinion, but I find the game's constant, agonizing insistence of Rico being a beloved hero that does no wrong ever to tug on my suspension of disbelief way, way harder than just accepting that blowing everything up is okay normally. You're telling me that the base I just nuked from orbit, wiping out an entire mountain, was only staffed with evil military dudes, AND there's a convenient repair crew that'll undo all the damage I cause, AND the police station I am very clearly walking into with a rocket launcher and killing everyone in is conveniently replaced by armed men expressly chosen by the general I'm up against, AND I can intentionally run people down on the street and nobody will even care... I have a much easier time believing Gamera is a friend to all children and nobody in Townsville dies.)I mean, there's a hell of a lot that's a positive about this game, but it's just structured badly and takes itself far too seriously, when its predecessor had neither issue. I would almost recommend it just to kill an afternoon or two, but the most damning thing here is that when I finish a game I enjoy, I tend to replay it again and again. I finished Just Cause 3 several months ago. I have not booted it up at all since. It's just not worth the time. Just Cause 3 had an impossibly high bar to live up to, and apparently it really was impossible, because it's this good and still just not good enough.

												In its current state, I cannot in good conscience recommend this game to most players. Do allows me to outline my issues in a nice list below:      Major Issues:              Garbage Performance -- I, like many others have had absolutely atrocious performance in this game. To clarify, I do not have an AMD processor or graphics card and have been able to run JC 2, Minecraft, CS:GO, and Far Cry 4 on full settings without any lag excluding minor and infrequent occurences. On lowest performance this game will launch and can run, however, FPS is always pretty damn low, fuel tank explosions almost stop the game from working, and sometimes certain towns and bases give random unexplained lag in addition to the random crashes and unstable exiting of game              Repetition and tedious chores -- The repetition of towns and whatnot was a major issue in JC 2, something we all thought would be addressed in "3." While this game has more variety and beauty, it is hard to enjoy with the combined lag and I am forced to complete almost the same exact missions for Dimah to disable these ♥♥♥♥ing FOWs. After the first few missions on Insula Dracon the game becomes completely repetitive. Not to mention we are forced to complete missions to get certain equipment.                    Soldiers and AI: The AI is absolutely atrocious seeing as though it will drive flaming vehicles, think it can drive a tank on a cliff, and fly a heli with a minigun directly in front of a heli with missiles. The AI is absurdly bad at finding Rico and doesn't really do much but pat people down and stand around staring at Rico. The soldiers do eventually become absurd and prevent the player from really doing much with the resources they are given.      Pros of the game:              New weapons and tools: The tether, wingsuit, and variety of guns and vehicles are immensely helpful and more interesting than JC2              Potential in story: The story has a huge potential, include the Bavarium nonsense, but I still feel that it was relatively unexplored and made to be highly cookie cutter and repetitive. Something interesting could have been done with the story, but instead the devs oped for the typical "we cannot let most glorious resource into bad hands, must kill bad guy and destroy. ALL YOUR BAVARIUM ARE BELONG TO US, SO WE CAN DESTROY AND HELP HUMANITY!" Nevermind the potential benefits of such a material.               Destruction potential: With this game, we are given the tools to do absolutely amazing things and to have great fun. Unfortunately, the cons that I outlined above make this very difficult.             Better AI than JC2: Although sub-par, the AI in this game makes an effort to call reinforcements and is reasonable. In JC 2 killing any enemy or shooting anywhere got heat. Here, if you kill all enemies and prevent reinforcements calls, nobody comes and heat disappears. It is also apparent that I can shoot on a mountain now and not have the enemy airforce deciding that random trees are in need of protection.  The game appears, at first glance to be open and expansive, and it appears that the player can destroy anything, but it quickly becomes clear the player can only destroy certain bridges and chaos items. Only new items to be destroyed are fluorescent lights, speakers, billboards, and bridges. That being said, I appreciate the hard work of people at square enix, this game is a blast when it runs correctly. That being said, the performance and obvious shortcomings of the game must be addressed eventually. It performance alone were fixed, I would give a positive review, but the other minor issues combined with performance make this experience far less enjoyable than it should be. Still, I have faith that the dev team will attempt to solve many current problems and perhaps issue some updates addressing lag and perhaps adding more towns, items, destruction, and maybe even multiplayer.EDIT: I need to make note of several things: Military bases make no ♥♥♥♥ing sense. Surely each base should have some radar system for early warning, but bases have random stuff and aren't specialized. There are no giant radar arrays, or fuel refineries, or naval bases, or even major airfields, just bases with a random AM antenna and three identical doppler radars so close to eachother that they wouldn't benefit whatsoever. In addition, it still makes no sense that random distillation towers and fuel tanks are just sitting in military bases -- nothing is specialized, just random stuff. This game also seems to lack the ability to properly handle the objects it creates as RAM usage shoots up through continued gameplay. If I wanted stuttering and slow response times I would have turned on the presidential debates.

												Bullets and missiles whiz past my head as I speed through the night sky, surfing on a plane. The artillery of a whole nation seems to be focused on my annihilation, while I fire rocket after rocket at the ground below. The deafening roar of the engines and the air-sucking booms of coutless explosions are my soundtrack. If this was a film, it would be the movie’s climax, when the hero does the impossible. In Just Cause 3, Avalanche’s latest destruction-obsessed action romp, it’s the opening scene.  For Rico Rodriguez, the game’s handsome, bearded protagonist – a professional racer turned tyrant-toppler – it’s just another day at work. He blows up military bases for breakfast, and for lunch, he tears down bridges while the army of an evil dictator – moustachioed cartoon villain Di Ravello – drives across. He’s a one man army, a superhero in jeans, and he’s done this all before. But this time, the explosions are bigger, the toys are more varied, and everything has just become a little bit more ridiculous. I don’t call Rico a superhero lightly. Avalanche’s third destruction sandbox is as much a superhero game as Rocksteady’s Arkham series, at least when it comes to the action. Our leading man can take down entire armies, fly across islands, and even survive the explosion of a grenade. Once, while minding my own business, gliding across a mountain range, I was hit by a missile. I got back up again and stole a helicopter, which I then dropped on top of a tank. I’d like to see Batman attempt that.With Just Cause 3, the writers have leaned directly into its b-movie comparisons. The story is a simple one, and is led by a host of zany, off the wall characters. Mario comedically  brings about numerous terrible ideasand spearheads one of the funnier missions in the game. Di Ravello is a compelling, but also by the books dictator. He hates everyone but himself, kills innocents, etc. For the most part, any type of cutscene in Just Cause 3 is forgettable. But I don’t think anyone is expecting a philosophical masterpiece from a game that begins with its main character hanging upside down from a helicopter.While little may have been expected of the story, it would be nice if the game built its story missions around using the strengths of the game. Missions often call for you to use your parachute/wingsuit combination in a variety of ways , but as the game went on, I found myself tiring of being forced to perform certain objectives. It felt as if I could do them by myself, without the help of the story, so there was no real reason to interact with them. The story feels like an afterthought to some of the more exciting stuff than can be found within Just Cause 3’s world.Possibly the largest thing you will spend your time doing in Just Cause 3 is liberating the many cities of Medici. These areas of interest will typically contain a list of things that must be destroyed or taken over, such as a generator, billboard, radio tower, or police station. Though numerous, watching them explode is never tiring. It’s clear Avalanche Studios wants Just Cause 3 to be the kind of game you can sit down and have mindless fun with and these cities are good examples of just that. There were numerous times where I would get in the rhythm of taking over Medici and completely lost track of time. It’s just a great way to have fun watching all sorts of things explode into flames.When you are not freeing the people of Medici, you will be probably be taking part in some of the many challenges strewn throughout the open world. These challenges are very reminiscent  to other open-world games and consist of car races, wing suit challenges, and the popular “blow everything up around you” objectives. For the most part, these side challenges are just another way to kill some time and relax. They never become too difficult or complex, they simply exist as a way to focus the player on one of Just Cause 3’s mechanics. These missions can be easily overlooked if you want, but they do provide mods that can be helpful at times.Just Cause 3’s new modification system adds some excitement to some areas of the game, while doing very little for others. As you earn more modifications for your grenades, you can have them explode on contact, or explode only when they connect with a certain object,be that an enemy, destructible object, etc.. The game also hides the ability to zoom in with weapons behind these modifications, but it is earned rather early on. While the mods available can provide some thrills, it does feel like there is some unexplored potential within the system.The controls are basically fine. I didn’t have any particular issues playing through on mouse and keyboard once I got used to the way everything worked, with the exception that vehicles (planes and the wingsuit, in particular) are a bit finicky on the keyboard because they really demand analogue controls. You might get a bit confused by the number of keys you need when swooping around – right-click to grapple, Space to open/close parachute, Shift to accelerate your grapple, CTRL to disconnect your grapple, E to activate your wingsuit – but I suspect that’d happen on a gamepad anyway, and I got used to it pretty fast.The graphics and physics of this game are what gives form to the carnage that Rico unleashes upon his enemies, and they are impressive. At max settings the PC version is stunning, with an enormous draw distance and incredible detail at distances both close and afar. The physics engine is remarkably stable too, considering the shenanigans that you can instigate with the grappling hook and tethers. It also allows for some amazing destructibility, although when things get too crazy, the frame rate can take a dive as a consequence.The game had network problems at various points in the time I was playing it. While an online connection is not required, you will always be logged in to Square Enix’s servers at startup. When the connection is lost to these servers, the game comes to a crashing halt for 30 seconds as it tries to reconnect, regardless of whatever it is that you were in the middle of doing. Also the game has horrendous load times. Just Cause 3 has the worse load times of any game in years. Gunplay in the Just Cause series has never been anything to brag about. That continues with Just Cause 3 as you never feel totally in  control when using a weapon.As for the actual gun selection, your options are varied. You can obtain all sorts of assault rifles as well as side arms. You constantly roll with a special weapon, which can range from your standard RPG to a gun that calls in airstrikes on whatever location you point it to. The variation in weapon sets makes destroying the many statues satellite dishes immensely satisfying.When you’re not waiting for it to load, Just Cause 3 is an incredibly fun game. Crisp visuals and a clever soundtrack bring all the explosions to life. Even with the violence and destruction, it manages to maintain a lighter tone than the Far Cry games, without sliding into the outright silliness of Saints Row. But, it’s still silly enough. Dropping boats on satellite dishes, tying enemy soldiers to exploding gas tanks, and grappling, wingsuiting, and parachuting the length and breadth of beautiful Medici, just to blow the crap out of it. Just Cause 3 is an absolute blast.

												Starting to get VERY fed up with devs releasing unfinished games. The game itself is brilliant, it just runs like a pig. I don't have a high spec system, but I can run SW: Battlefront on High at a solid 60fps. This turd is so unoptimised and poorly coded that it ran at 60fps on high last night, then tonight it ran ok but crashed. After restarting it cant even reach 20fps with the same settings. Even with everything on low or off it's still EXACTLY the same frame rate.The lip snch goes out on every single cut scene, then catches up, then goes again.The frame rate goes from 60 to 20 randomly for no reason, but during massive explosions and shed loads of chaos on screen, it mostly copes fine. I'd expect with this amount of stuff going on it will drop of a few frames when things hot up, but it doesn't do too badly. It just randomly slows down with no obvious reason.So dissapointed as it seems like a really good game.Just cannot recommend it until they've fixed it. But then I thought that about Arkham Knight...Just to clarify on a few points - My system exceeds the minimum specs. Why would I complain about a game that runs badly if I dont meet the minimum specs.....? As I said, I changed everything to the lowest settings and it still ran the same, whereas the day of release it was on high and ran fine.I do know whats involved with coding a game. What I also understand is that money men get int he way of deveopment and demand the game is released before its been fully bug tested. It happens all the time. A few games are managed really well and make it out the door brilliantly - SW: Battlefront being the best example I've ever seen. And no, I wouldn't say JC3 is any more demanding specs wise than Battlefront. Yes, JC3 has more explosions and is a tiny bit more CPU intensive, but have you seen Battlefront on high settings? It's flippin beautiful. But more importantly, this is a AAA game made by experienced devs a good few years into a console's life, and with previous PC experience, I expected more.As for the running like a pig similie - i'd look up the word first if I were you. It's a figure of speech. And yes pigs do run quite quick, but when did you last see them running consistently for a long period? Hence the fairly accurate simile....Also I never said it was easy to make video games. But DICE managed it without lousy code with Battlefront. Yes lots of games are released these days with game breaking bugs - I still cant play Fallout 4 in my native resolution due to a bug and Arkham Knight still isnt fixed. But this will keep happening if we all just keep accepting it and saying, "Oh well, it'll be fixed at some point I suppose..."I did also say that the game itself seemed great. If they do fix all the bugs quickly I'd recommend the game wholeheartedly - I'm really enjoying what I can play of it.And lastly - no game should be released with this many bugs. Yes I understand that many arent having problems - but many are and it seems to be the code at fault - not many complaints can be put down to rigs not meeting minimumspec/driver updates etc.

												Just Cause 3 is great if you love Bollywood style action, a lot of freedom, and the ability to be creative with your explosions. I've sunk a lot of time into this game, roughly about 20 hours by my estimate (it's all been offline, more about that later) and I always find myself starting this game with another idea for something stupid to try. Like take a boat down a mountain and feel like you're in cool runnings, or try and build a catapult using the tether and some cars. The game is fun to explore, the movement system feels great, especially the wingsuit. The game is massive, and scaled appropriately to how fast you're going to be travelling most of the time. You could argue that the world is a little empty compared to some other modern sandboxes, but I think 'Spread out' is a better term. There's a lot to see in Just Cause 3, and if you find yourself driving a car at 200 km/h in a random direction, you're not ever going to have to backpedal to find something to do when you inevitably crash. The game is spread out in a way that you're constantly going "ooh what's that on the horizon?"Performance-wise, I have trouble with v-sync only. Everything else runs like a dream, and that's with a GTX 960. I get almost constant 60fps, with the occasional stutter, though it's very rare. I'm always suprised at how well the engine deals with having hundreds of physics objects hurtling around at once.The story is there. It's funny in places, with some cool scripted missions. But all of the scripted missions do have the option to put your own flair onto them, nothing is set in stone. You need to blow something up? How you do it is generally up to you.The side missions are sometimes dull, sometimes excellent. The flying and boating eventually get very samey. Especially since you're always in one of the small selection of planes/boats that appear in the game. The frenzy missions are complete garbage however. You basically get 90 seconds to run around with the game's weapon of choice, and blow up parts of an enemy base (generally one you just finished blowing up.) There are never any enemies in this mode, and it's often boring. The difficulty scale is all wrong, some involve a sniper rifle trying to shoot down radio towers, and another might be destroying fuel tanks with a helicopter equipped with missiles. It's just a dumbed-down version of what you just did, except a lot less exciting. This game mode could have easily been fixed if it had been about killing enemies however. Generally in the main game you're not spending most of your time fighting bad guys, you're picking off a few that are in your way and then you're getting away speedily. But having frenzy be about fighting waves of bad guys with a specific weapon would be a lot more fun IMHO. It would make you try out more weapons rather than just going for the biggest kaboom. Plus it would be a good reason to fight the varied array of types of enemies in the game. rather than just whizzing past them on the way to the nearest generator.The wingsuit missions brilliant are on the other hand, often showing off some of the most beautiful parts of the game while you get to really hone your wingsuit skills. (This will come naturally, by the time you're an hour in you'll be using the wingsuit a lot!) And the Speed missions where you drive an exploding car towards a group of soldiers then bail out before it explodes are a more fun version of the driving missions. Which aren't races for some reason, just a time trial.The always online aspect is annoying, I would recommend starting Steam in offline mode to play this since there doesn't seem to be an option to switch it off. If you play online it WILL get in the way of you playing the game.Overall, the game is lacking in some respects. There aren't enough types of vehicles, or weapons, or missions. No submarines or scuba gear ( that I've found) despite a beautiful ocean just screaming to be explored. No multiplayer, which was one of the best additions to JC2 although it was a mod. And I can't help but feel like this is all being held back for future DLC.My conclusion: Just Cause 3 is fun, a lot of fun. The game feels great and looks great. If you enjoy making up your own challenges, having a beautiful world to explore and watching things explode and fly around, then this game is for you. I love it to bits, and I can play for hours on end and always have some other insane thing I want to attempt right before I switch off.But do I think you should buy it?Yes.But in a year's time. Wait for the DLC, see if the game is more full of content, see if they add multiplayer. See if they manage to optimise it a bit better! Next Christmas you'll pick up the full game much cheaper then you will now, and you'll have a blast with it. But right now, there's a bit too much missing content for me to recommend it for the price. If you can stand waiting, then by all means do.

It's colorful, bright, smooth, and the explosions are incredibly enjoyable2) The sounds are ok, and the voice actors are really funny and well done.3) I liked the music, even though they are quiet and you don't really hear them.4) The gameplay is fun and addictive. I love the wingsuit, I enjoy moving through the mountains with my gears, the shooting is fun. Though I had to remap a bit my controls because I wanted it to feel like Just Cause 2, it plays well, and it is fun.5) The explosions and the grappling hook... Nothing else to say, it's just well done. The game become somewhat a physics-based game with the ability to use your grappling.6) Huge map, a lot of places to blow up.7) The leaderboard thigie is neat (i dont care if im not as good as my friends)Cons1) You won't give a crap about the story/missions, as for Just Cause 2.2) The map is too big. Yes, I said it was a pro, but my main problem is when you try to go from an island to the other. If you don't have a jet, it'll take forever to crosse the water.3) I still don't get how the chaos work for this episode - might change this point once I figure it out.4) As stated above,5) the optimization,6) IS7) ABSOLUTLY8) POSITIVELY9) HORRRRRRIIIIIIIDDDDD10) Having to log into Square Enix servers for everything, so if their down the game props you every few minutes, or every time you open the map11) Initial Load times, the main menu--game start is dreadful, and yes i've heard of the SSD vs HDD12) Gets repetitive quicklyConclusionOverall, this game is a fun experience, if you like blowing things up and killing people like there is no tomorrow (which is my case so...). If you want deep story, dark intrigue, multiplayer mode or realistic gunfight, just ignore this game. I think that if you liked Just Cause 2, you'll like this one too. It's no where near perfect, it surely isn't as good as JC2, but it's fun, and it gives you explosion, so it's nice.

Posted: February 22, 2016
												Ah Just Cause 3, a good game? A bad game? A fun game? A boring game?...  If these were statements instead of questions they'd all be true of JC3. This is a game of systems and mechanics and what is there works great, however I think sadly there isn't enough mechanics to keep the game interesting all of the time.A typical play session of JC3 would be travel some where and blow everything up, then rinse and repeat. It doesn't matter why you're there and the context of your destruction, that is what it boils down to, explosions. Now nearly every game ever made could be described in such over simplified terms and I know that, but what JC3 fails to do is disguise this fact in a way that you don't realise that is all your doing.Now don't get me wrong, how you go about exploding everything around you is immense fun. Grenades, rockets, grenade launchers, high jacking Tanks, combat Helicopters, fighter jets, using grappling hooks to pull down structures, topple fuel tanks etc etc...  it goes on and on and it also looks really good too, the explosions in particular are something to behold. They have made this a spectacle and it is awesome to see, at least for a while.Like with any spectacle, it has a shelf life, you can't watch fireworks for 30 hours straight and not get bored, but in small bursts here and there... fireworks are great! That pretty much sums up the game for me, good in small bursts but it does get tired quickly over an extended play period.Does this make it a bad game? Not in my book, but it does make it a shallow game and sadly an imperfect experience. Difficulty isn't high (which I am fine with by the way) so the challenge will come from destroying things in the most spectacular way or efficient way you can think of.The story missions are ok and the final boss is an expected anti climax, but there is a narrative if you're interested. There is loads to do, upgrades to unlock, challenge missions that test your skills and collectables, you aren't short of content but like me you might find yourself asking if you *want* to do it all...  as I said,  you'll be more or less doing the game thing over and over again in a very noticeable way which at times felt like a chore.It is what it is, it never advertised itself as anything other than a fun explosive romp, so no complaints that it delivered on it's promise, but whether that will be enough for you or not, will boil down to own personal tastes.

Posted: September 19, 2016
												So much potential!Starting with the good, the game is gorgeous. The default keybindings are different, but in the end make for better gameplay. The story is also much better than the second game; no more factions that were identical in feel. A lot of the story missions are very cool. The addition of the wingsuit is a nice idea, but not useful for combat purposes. (I only mention this because it's very easy to accidentally engage the wingsuit during a fight because it's the same hotkey as "Use". Nothing like slamming your face into a helicopter instead of commandeering it.) The addition of the contracting grapple tethers is awesome, and is the only marked improvement over the second game unless you're a graphics snob.Now for the bad. If you like the second game, there's not enough to see here. The game is not optimized for PC at all. I spent 20 minutes dialing back my settings because after playing for 2-5 minutes, the memory leak causes the framerate to drop down to 1-5 frames per second. (Think Batman: Arkham Knight)Also, it's ironic that the enemy forces are named the DRM, because the game requires a constant internet connection. Even if you disable the Leaderboard nonsense, the game will lock up and give you a reconnection screen in the middle of your activity. (Keep in mind, this is a single-player game.) I even firewalled the game, which kept it from bothering me, but after a week, the game required me to be able to connect to the internet in order to launch.The game has 1/4 as much content as the second game in every way. Meaning, you will complete it in a quarter of the time that it took to play the second game. But it goes beyond that. As you fly over a road, there is rarely a car travelling down it, there are a quarter as many bases or interesting sites to discover. The landscape feels barren. It's a sprawling, gorgeous, Italian-like landscape, and yet there's very little to do in it. The second game had awesome discoveries like the giant satellite dish, the ski lodge, the huge urban city full of skyscrapers. This game has no surprises. The landscape has different climates, but the locales are uninspired, and rotate between 5 different types. The climax of the second one was so epic, with a huge showdown. The ending fight of #3 felt like it came out of a game 15 years old, and had very little going on at all.I wanted to like it, and I had fun playing it, but I'm feeling cheated. When you're liberating the populace, it's a blast, but then you fly over 2 minutes (miles and miles) of empty land to find something else to do. Such a shame. Did they want me to pump money into the DLC packs to have a complete experience?

												As much as I want to, I cannot recommend this game. I've played through Just Cause 2 mulitple times and enjoyed each moment of it, but this? This has been a horrendous mess. Before I go on, I should point out that i'm using an i7-6700k, 16GB of RAM, and a GTX 1080, displaying onto a 1080p screen (I really should go to 4k). Not even this could handle the s***storm that is Just Cause 3.I hadn't even started playing the game when I encountered my first problem. The game would crash on boot in fullscreen mode. A little bit of tweaking meant I could boot it in borderless windowed mode. After getting to the main screen I set everything at ultra and selected play, to which I was instantly greeted with 25 FPS constantly. I rebooted the game multiple times, turned down all of the settings, made sure I was on the latest video drivers, and even rebooted the system, yet nothing worked. A fresh install did nothing and i decided to call it a night.12 or so hours later, I decided to try again. Oddly enough, it decided to run at 60fps with everything on ultra. Happy with the outcome, I went through the intro again and began playing. 1 mission in and the game was already experiencing bugs. After the helicopter that was supposed to pick me up didn't arrive (which I actually found rather funny), the game decided to crash. I brushed this off and tried again, yet it crashed after an hour or so of gameplay. I gave up.Later that day, determined to play a game that looked so beautiful and so much fun, I tried once again to keep the game running. I opened all of my monitoring software up to make sure I wasn't running out of resources and began playing. Of course, it didn't crash for about 5 hours. When it did, none of the software was showing any problems with the computer, so it must've been the game.I continued to play for a few days or so, and each time it would crash after 4-5 hours of gameplay, which while it is annoying if you spend long periods of time gaming like me, wasn't as bad as the game running at 25 FPS. Several of the challenges I attempted within the game had a couple of bugs here and there, which was a pain to get around, especially within the crash bomb challenges as the bomb explosion is tiny and does very little damage for an explosion so big. It was only after the game crashed in the middle of a mission for the third time that i decided it was time to write this review.I will admit, there are some parts of the game I did enjoy. The wingsuit mechanic is very well done and while difficult at first, once mastered, does become a very useful tool for getting around the place. The upgrade system works well and the leaderboards feature is a great way of competing with friends and adds an extra challenge to the game to complete in your free time if you wish. The vehicle models and mechanics (well, maybe apart from the bike mechanics) were very well done and made me want to actually drive around instead of wingsuiting everywhere. Additionally, the character models and the scenery in general is beautifully done and really captured the mediterranean atmosphere.If you can look past the problems with the game and really enjoyed the previous one, pick it up, although wait for it to be on sale just in case you do have problems with it, as spending £10 on a broken game is better than spending £40 on a broken game. The problems I had will not be there for everyone and if you do pick this up, you may have no problems with it at all, but due to my experience with it, I cannot recommend purchasing this game.I will eventually complete this game and attempt to 100% it, but for now, I think I'm going to give it a break.

It's everything I wanted from the next instalment in the franchise.I have heard some people complain that there's not much content beyond liberating bases and completing challenges. It often disconnects me from the servers, making me often have to reconnect, sometimes it won't reconnect and I have to go into offline mode where it will try to reconnect me every 5 minutes when I pause the game as well. I know you want to keep your game out of the hands of those pesky pirates and I respect that but at least make sure that the people who do purchase it are not inconvenienced by your measures.That said, the game runs fairly well on my set-up with I7-4790K, GTX 770 and 16 GB of RAM. Running it on high and maintaining 60 FPS most of the time. FPS drops are present but rather rare.I personally would give this game a solid 8.5/10.

												Note:  This was a review from back in January, I am reposting it in hopes that more people see it.Runs like crap. And not just frames per second wise, there is plenty of crashes and stuttering to be had. Has some pretty insane memory leaks too.Forced online login. Worst. Decision. Ever. I have had to block JC3 in my firewall and run steam in offline mode just to be able to play "offline".Lots of little things missing like being able to sprint and crouch. This isn't an on rails shooter, why limit Ricos maneuverability to just the grapple and parachute? Yes, the game was obviously made around those mechanics, but given that it is an open world game, WE should be allowed to choose how we want to play. Those that don't want to sprint or crouch behind cover simply won't. Adding those are only a benefit to those that would enjoy it and you lose nothing.Bottom line: explosions are pretty, but the game play feels stale. Pick up JC2 with all the DLC and you will have much more fun.Edit April 5th, 2016: Couple of patches later, performance is a bit better but still not great. It is clear they put a sub par team into this game compared to the likes of GTA 5 which I can run just fine with extended draw distance which has a million and a half more things going on at once than in this game. Still not recommended, save your money.Edit August 18th, 2016: If you are STILL on the edge of buying this game, DON'T. RUN AWAY. Since my last update, they have done nothing in terms of supporting their game other than adding support for their constant line of DLC. They kept saying they were going to try and fix issues with the game, but they haven't.. its just been "Uhh... err... weeell... LOOK AT THE SHINY DLC YOU CAN BUY!!"

content:
Posted: June 25, 2016
												As big as the world map is, the actual game's content is very thin. So thin, they've gated every possible thing in the game via trials , collectables, and conquesting the world map. Instead of making traversal easy, its tedious. You haven't unlocked the fast travel node? Prepare to glide for 11 kilometers to the mission destination. You nabbed an enemy tank and want to capture it for future use? Sorry. You can't do that, you need to go gather 20+ collectables around the map to get any of the actual worthwhile vehicles.The destruction gimmick is fine, but this game reminds me of Red Faction: Guerrilla. You see everything this game has to offer in a very short time frame, and then are forced to wade yourself through the most tedious game padding imaginable to get to the next story beat. The story itself isn't compelling, the only compelling thing about this game is that it took up 50 gigs on my hard drive and I wanted to free up space.To go back on why this game reminds me of Red Faction: Guerrilla, it is because the gunplay isn't good, and the majority of the game, whether you want to admit it and regardless of how many gimmicks you throw in the mix, you will be engaging in this sub par gunplay. Previous games of this kind have done this better, I would recommend them over this. Particularly something like Mercenaries 1+2, where the gunplay was better, the destruction was more fun, and the gameplay loop was much tighter and more rewarding. Even the story was more compelling with factions that mattered with branching paths for story and multiple endings.

Posted: December 1, 2015
												I'm disappointed, Avalanche.The game looks and sounds great - but poor performance (hopefully this will be patched) and lack of multi-GPU support is a big let down. Ridiculous loading times, even on an SSD - and I must be missing the option to skip the intro. Watching Rico blow up the boat in the distance was nice the first time but I don't want to wait a minute every time I start the game to get to the actual gameplay. I think this may be something to do with the "online" element of the game as it seemed to take a long time to login after this.I've been informed that the studio that made JC2/Mad Max (Avalanche Studios Stockholm) didn't make JC3 (New York) - so that partly explains the rift in performance.If you lose connection to Square Enix servers while ingame a big annoying message interrupts gameplay, asking you to retry connection or go to offline mode - why couldn't you just automatically go offline and periodically retry and just notify me in the corner?Rico feels like an OAP when he isn't in the parachute or wingsuit. No rolling or sprinting.Some elements of the HUD are poor - waypoints/objectives are hard to see sometimes (tiny white markers and text blend in with the background). What happened to the minimap?AI effectiveness seems to vary a lot - some are capable of sniping you out of a full speed helicopter, but get close and they can barely hit you. Enemies have tendancy to spawn right next to you without warning.On the upside - voice acting is a lot better (no BOLOOOO SANTOSIII), driving is slightly improved over JC2 (though still a bit iffy) and the writing gives you a few laughs. The improved tethering is a welcome addition and the wingsuit is great. The game also tells you what you need to do to liberate areas now which is a helpful addition.There is a good game in there but these issues are spoiling it for me.

Posted: June 11, 2016
												So like if you like just cause 2 you will like 3. It brings over some of the mods from 2 into 3 like the multi grappling hook and the turbo on a smaller scale. Most of the vehicles I felt may be kinda useless when most of my traveling was done with the normal wing suit. Oh and do the challenges as soon as you can because they really help you out in the game. Its beautiful and their are plenty of things to explore and EXPLOSIONS!  As for those complaining about how they think the game runs poor... well for one i have a gtx 970 and a i7 5690k with 16gb of ram  but here is the kicker, I'm running it at 1440p with 50+ fps  avg on the max settings on win 10 64bit on an ssd with out any issues. Now as far as the ram issue goes my system idles at 1.4 gb ram and playing this game it goes to ~4.5gb at an eyeball avg of 40% cpu load so....yea. And at least for me this has been constant performance from day 1 owning the game and I bought it maybe a few days after it came out. Game is rock solid performance even on my brothers 960gtx he runs 720p at  60+fps and never encounters slowdown on 4 gb of ram on an 4 year old amd fx 8000, heck this will work just off the apu in an i7 at low settings 30 fps. As far as Ati cards go the reason their so poor on this particular game is the way they handle mass textures like explosions  where as the nvida cards are made more in mind for sudden demand in memory and particle calculations so they have a much easier time with this game so i would blame it more on the manufacture for not supporting through software in such a way that it compensates for those cards weaknesses.   But just to let you all know sometimes it can be the reverse for other games and it's not all dependent on the engine that the game runs on but the support given to that engine by that company that makes the card, it's a 2 way street. Sadly it seems that ATI still is not up to snuff with their driver support for this AAA game that's been out for a while (witch the consoles are also ATI/AMD machines). Avalanche Engine only has 5 games on it their is bound to be less support for it where as games like DOOM are based of UE4 and almost all games produced with that brand new engine run really well on most cards and their is a lot more driver support for because of all the games ( https://wiki.unrealengine.com/Category:Games ) that's like +30 games in development on this one engine.Those of you having issues with the game their are a few steps you can takeStart the game in the lowest possible settings and slowly adjust them one by one up until you get a crash and report it to Avalanche.validate the files through steam if your getting crashesupdate your video card drivers>try the gameuninstall the game>restart>install the game>restart>try the gameuninstall your video card drivers>restart>reinstall them>restart>try the game If it was working at one point do a system restore by going to start>search>system restore>pick a time when you know it was working. hope this helped a bitTLDR: If you like 2 then your going to like 3. Only worry about the game working if you have an low end ATI card or a >$300 computer (console).

												Hello! I'm Rit. I'm no real particular fan of the just cause series, but I do enjoy sandboxes in general, and well my friend coaxed me into buying the game so I could play alongside him! As such. You can trust that I didn't have any 'hype' or bias to the game. I've had a vague interest in the game and initially didn't even want to consider buying it. Well, I did, and here is my review of it. I'll have to note that it gets ridiculously detailed, so I'll give the best shot at a Tl;Dr I can, then below I'll put the full details! I advice any developers who are reading this go through that section. I have a...lot to say.Tl;Dr - In general, the game is fun. It is "Good" but it has not impressed me. Perhaps the strongest part of the game is not exploding things, not blowing up entire bases or causing chaos. Nope. It's the wingsuiting. And I love that, I do, I spend most of my time wingsuiting. But unless you feel like doing lots of tedious challenges and doing the same repetitive takeovers of bases, then don't get this game. If you're into that stuff, if you're great at finding ways to blow things up in the next greatest way? Go for it. But I'm 40 hours in, and I felt like I've seen most of what the game has to offer. Save for 1 weapon, a couple of vehicles, and trains. I recommend it if you're buying it on sale, not for full price.Details here! It wouldn't fit in Steam![www.dropbox.com]So now the conclusion. And yes, the positives weren't as long. But eh. Honestly I don't have much more to say, I'm sure you already know about the better tether and the better explosions already and I don't have much to add to what most trailers and people already say. So...Is it a good game..? Yes. Does it compare well to JC2? It's a fine sequel, but that's all it is. As much as I'd like to say the slight improvements to the tether and bombs are all you need, and as much as I'd like to say that the wingsuit is a fantastic innovation that sells the game. But it's not. It's a great transportation system that occasionally leaves me just flying around idly, but I can't say it's the thing I've spent most of my time on. I personally think they took JC2, made a few improvements in some of the areas, prettied it up, then added the wingsuit. And that's about it. It's a better JC2 (Except for the driving) And that's the thing. I'm judging it so harshly because while JC2 was very unique and thus attracted lots of people despite the flaws. JC3 just feels like another iteration, only making 'safe' steps forward. "Oh modders did this and it was super popular, we'll put that in" It doesn't feel like any real risks were taken, and it doens't feel like they've added anything real worth it content wise to the game.So do I recommend it? Yes. Get it on the cheap. I got it for half price. $40 compared to Australia's regular $80. If you can get it in your regional equivalent for that price, go for it. It's a nice game for that price. I can't say it's good for full price though.

												The main problem with this game is the graphics and character control.  The graphics are just plain bad.  It looks like it would be at home on PS3, which was great...eight years ago.  The character's movements, especially in combat, don't feel very up to date either.  It's one of those things where you can run around too easily while taking heavy gunfire from several enemies that don't move or take cover or act at all like actual people.  Driving and flying are also quite poor. It's basically identical to Just Cause 2, which was good in its time but that time has passed.Also my pc surpasses the recommended specs yet I still run into choppy gameplay at times.  I play several other games that were released recently on the highest graphical settings with no problem and they look a hell of a lot better than this, so I'm inclined to believe it's either poor programming or a collection of bugs.To throw some positive light on this poorly executed game I must say that the gameplay is enjoyable.  Who doesn't like an open world where everything can be victim to exploding?  Also the improvements with the grappling hook make for some fun and unique ways to destroy things and kill enemies.  All in all it's really too bad that the graphics and character control ruined what was an excellent idea for a game.

												Get Just Cause 2, and then get some mods. That is, to a degree what this game is but there are also some negative points below.Just Cause 3 is essentially a waste of time, its only selling points are its new desired game mechanics, vehicles, and weapons. The map is artifically made to look bigger but in the broad scheme of things its actually very small and under-populated with content.DRM, not only the name of the games antagonist (look at us we're meta!), but also the fact that it almost routinely forces you to go online in order to launch the game. I have almost no recorded time in-game because I try to run it in offline mode whenever possible. Ive actually beaten the game and put in at least 40 hours. Being online slows down the game and it's already a poorly optimized lump of crap. (I run a GTX970 btw).The Story itself. Meh, okay. I didn't expect a mastery of story-telling with a series like just cause. What I also didn't expect was a game with only a short afternoon's worth of actual story missions. In JC2 there were other missions that were offered between "Agency" missions, which gave the game a lot of content since these varied in type and depth. Perhaps stealing a car from a private island, or blowing up a satelite array, or hijacking a car with someone in it to kidnap them! NOT THIS TIME AROUND! No! Just LIBERATING TOWNS, over and over and over....and over. Far Cry 4 must have made a lot of money I guess, since its the common architecture for current games. Liberating towns in JC3 is fun the first maybe 15 times you do it, but it begins to get old quick. Then you want to return to the story and... HM NOT YET, GET OUT THERE AND GRIND BY LIBERATING MORE THINGS. Don't do a variety of missions that are almost equally as engaging as the story ones, no! Just go do whatever! It's your game remember!?!?Considering I couldnt even get into the game because "square enix servers are not responding"I'm not so sure it is my game.

Posted: July 18, 2016
												Just Cause 3 is probably one of my favorite games I played this year, I've had an amazing time playing it and I'm almost done with the story, and yet still will go finish off capturing the world. I recommend this game with a huge caveat. IF YOU CAN PLAY IT, you're going to have an absolutely brilliant time.    With that being said, I have an Alienware Alpha and put in 16 gigs of ram, and had no problems.  I did have 1 crash, and it lost my save game onces (A HUGE problem mind you, as I lost about 12 hours of progress, but got it back in maybe half the time).  It has a number of decent size bugs clearly. However when it works?  It works!  There's a base, I soften it up with a few strafing runs with a military jet I stole, til my plane gets shot down by SAM attacks.  I eject over the base, and parachute in, as my plane "lands" in a huge explosion taking out one of the many critical targets.  I continue to work my way through the base, killing soldiers and blowing up stuff, while an attack helicopter arrives to kill me.  Sadly I haven't hacked a SAM to be friendly, and the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ is shooting me often enough that I don't have the time to at the moment.  I go to the tried and true method.  I use my grappling hook to tie him to the ground, and have in reel in. Pulling him out of the air, making him unstable and down he goes, directly into me.  The entire time I'm laughing and having a blast, it's so much fun to just rain hell down on an unsuspecting enemy.    The tether gun is a thing of pure magic, you can take any two objects and fling them at each other with a ton of force, this can be two structures, a building and a guard, A guard's head and another guard's butt.  Just that one weapon would have made an extremely fun game. Some of my favorite moments are when I'm reloading, and I'm getting shot up, it's taking too long so I find the shooter and now have two choices, either zip line and kick him in the face, or tether him to the nearest object (bonus points if it's explodable) and send him face first to his death.   Waiting on a reload no longer is necessary. Then there's the wingsuit.  I started hating the device, thinking it was impossible to use effectively.  Within two hours I was flinging myself across kilometers of land without a second thought.   Grapple the ground, pull up, reel into the ground and slingshotting between points faster than almost any other object in the game.  The speed, the excitement, the rush.     The wingsuit is to movement, what the tether gun is to combat, a redefinition of an idea that every game thinks they mastered.There's so many moment, and there's a HUGE world to conquer in this game.   However there's a few caveats. The missions are a mix.  Some are absolutely amazing (There's a few where the player is doing stunts worthy of James Bond, or better)  And some are defend a point missions which are frustrating or dull.    The story alongside pretty much every mission isn't just weak.  It's bad.  I mean half the time I don't know exactly what people are talking about and the other half I just don't care.   The third Island has about three to four times the first two area's landmass (Note all islands are accessible at any time, so you can truly free roam from the first moment) But about the same amount of content, so there's just more open area. However none of that matters when you're ripping a base to shred with some wire, some guns, and a RPG, grenade launcher or any other weapon of destruction you can find, as enemies flail helplessly against you.  Overall I'd say if you can run it, it's a fantastic game.  You're going to have a good time destroying and toppling an enemy regime.  But "If you can run it" is sadly a bigger question than it should be.   If you have a computer that can handle it though, no question, hands down, this is a great game.

												Just Cause 2 is a really good game. I really want to love Just Cause 3, but I can't. It's probably my most regretted purchase of a game. The multi grapple is great, and the more detailed destruction physics are a blast. Aside from that, it is a much worse game than JC2.The controls are an absolute abomination, the vehicle and movement physics are atrocious, and the game has one of the worst cases of multiple-bound controls ever with no way to fix it despite having plenty of buttons on PC. Avalanche clearly knew this, because they made everything very sticky and semi-automated to try and compensate for it instead of fixing the underlying problems. The result is the most frustrating experience imaginable, spending most of your time stuck in animations or an out of control vehicle wishing you could do the simple, cool thing you want to do. Just go watch some youtube videos of someone blowing up a few bases and you'll get 95% of the fun of this game without any of the frustration.Possibly the single worst thing is that the one thing that does work right, the wingsuit, is deliberately gimped. Pitching up is extremely weak compared to all the other inputs, which eliminates the possibility for skillfully skimming just above the ground - especially combined with another "feature", where if you get REALLY close the the ground, you instantly dump your velocity and slow to a crawl. You wind up just taking easy routes higher up where you can't really maintain much speed, and just resorting to fast traveling everywhere since traversal is no fun.

Though every time, and it happened quite often, i enjoyed when the AI flew their aircraft into a wall or a bridge or a cliff - that was genuinely funny. For the gameplay part - everything was too prone to explode, though everything exploding was a part of the game style, it was poorly done - for example i was tethering a boat and i accidentally pulled it over a small rock and it got airborne for half a second and the boat exploded. I really needed that boat. As for the story part - it's short, like it's really short, though it's "cleverly" lengthened by the need to liberate provinces. It's fun, but gets monotone. The ending boss fight was boring and a huge disappointment, also the end itself. The end credits are unskippable and go on for a long time

Posted: January 30, 2016
												Just cause 3 is different to JC2. If you take that on board you'll have more fun!I really like JC3 although it does have flaws. The wingsuit is amazing, exploring the map is an enjoyable experience and experimenting with the mechics is endlessly hilarious. There's plenty of things to do and I found the game easily ate up 50+ hrs while liberating all the settlements, completing the storyline and getting all the collectables.Once you've done all that you're kinda left to your own devices. Unless you actively enjoy experimenting with the mechanics of the game, or happen to enjoy stunts there's not an awful lot left to do. You can reinstate individual locations and liberate them again but it's a little bit of an empty process with no goal. As a single player open world game this is a huge mistake not to add some kind of value to the game after it has been completed (DLC is on it's way but we don't have any idea of what content it will provide yet)This is just the tip of the iceberg when it comes to flaws. There's design decisions that leave me baffled: no FOV slider or choice of camera angles (I think they ran out of control pad buttons to use lol), assigning boost to different buttons depending on the type of vehicle you're in. The weird delay you get between stunt jumping on a vehicle and being able to grapple. The main island being virtually empty. The dumb AI. The crashing. The list goes on and on. The lack of keybindings. Jeez I could talk about the flaws for a LONG time as there are so many and they really do effect the expereince negatively.Having said all that, I'm a huge fan of the Just CAuse franchise and the possibilities the game yields. As such I'm ok with overlooking the flaws. I spend a lot of my time stunting or creating silly experiments in JC3 and it's easily been worth the money paid. Will you enjoy it as much? I'm not sure... I suppose it depends how you play games. If you follow the missions and complete the story before moving on you may miss a lot about what makes JC3 so unique and enjoyable. However if you're more creative with your gameplay then you'll likely get a lot more from the experience.Either way I'm looking to the future now as the DLC shall be here soon (hopefully with more map content) and the JC2MP Team are working on a multiplayer mod for Just Cause 3.... which will change EVERYTHING!

content:
Posted: March 10
												Bottom Line - great fun but don’t trust the minimum specsThere’s four big things to do in this game: story mode, liberation, collectables, and challenges.The story mode really isn’t much, even compared to Just Cause 2.  Most of the characters aren’t very interesting and the missions really aren’t that novel but they do provide a break from the other parts of the game.The liberation is the big thing Just Cause has done for so long.  Basically, go in and blow up all the stuff with red paint on it.  But it ISN’T basic at all!  JC3 provides loads of ways to get that done from simply shooting at them to rocket launchers to tanks.  When you blow up all the red stuff in a base, your fellow rebels instantly swoop in at take over.  Liberating towns is a bit more complicated but only a bit more.  Every time you liberate a town or base, some challenges open up.There are several kinds of challenges from car/plane/boat races to handing you infinite ammo and seeing how much you can destroy in 2 minutes.  Depending on how well you do, you earn 0 to 5 stars (gears – whatever).  These are totaled up over different challenges to earn upgrades to your equipment like being able to hold more grenades or adding a nitro boost to vehicles you request.There are also many ad-hoc challenges that you can earn anytime just by playing the game.  These are things like number of kills without reloading, car jump distance, and distance travelled in a soap box car.  They will pop up in the upper right when one of them is getting near or above your personal best.It isn’t just your own score up there, though, and it isn’t every person that ever played the game including dozens of cheaters.  It’s your friends that have played the game plus a few random people (which will be replaced by more friends if they start playing the game).  I’ve enjoyed that quite a bit – it hit just the right mix of challenge and attainability for me.The collectables are mostly pretty blah.  I did enjoy collecting vehicles simply because some of them are a real challenge to get to the chop shops but the rewards for finding all the tapes/vintage parts/shrines didn’t seem to come anywhere near justifying the work you have to do to get them and there's not much fun in homing in on them or flying to a ? mark on the map.The game's grapple hook is hugely fun!  This is where your own creativity really gets a workout.  With the grapple you can pull yourself quickly forward, latch on to a car and pull yourself on top of it, latch yourself to a ledge and pull yourself up, and lots more.  You can also hold down the button after attaching and attach the other side of the grapple to something else, tethering them together.  Holding down shift then pulls those two things together.  It’s amazing what you can do with this simple mechanic!A word on the controls, which have been getting a pretty bad wrap.  The controls for the wing suit, grapple, and airplanes seem pretty bad at first.  The grapple just has a lot of functionality, though, and the wingsuit/airplanes are simply supposed to be hard to control.  You’ll get used to the grapple pretty quickly and some practice will get you flying well enough in the wingsuit and airplanes.There’s definitely some not-so-good stuff.First the specs.  A lot of folks with minimum specs are getting really poor performance.  If you’re anywhere near the lower bounds, keep your finger on the Refund button.  If you’re having performance issues you can try a few tweaks but don’t go over that 2 hour limit!For whatever reason the game makes you sit there for several seconds before it finally decides to get on with loading the game.  It’s nice in that you don’t have to interact at all to get into the game but why does it make you sit and watch Rico on the beach for so long!?  At least you've got time to go make a drink while the game loads up.There’s also just one and only one save.  If your save gets corrupted or you aren’t thinking and start a new game up… oops.  Be sure to go into the Documents\Square Enix\Just Cause 3\ folder and back up your save folder every now and again, just in case.There are some other nagging bugs but nothing too terrible.At full price the DLC might be a bit expensive for what you get but they are pretty fun and well worth it if you find them on sale.  (The XL version of the game includes all three.)  You’ll have access to them about a quarter of the way through the game and they’ll be a pretty good challenge at that point.  You might want to lay off some of the weapons you get, though, because they are devastating.  (Though it’s nice to be devastating from time to time.  ;)

												Sometimes, this game is incredibly satisfying to play.They way they've improved the grappling mechanics, and introduced the wingsuit, opening up a wide array of opportunities for intense takedowns and death defying stunts.But the game as a whole feels empty.Just Cause 3's brief half baked plot is riddled with needless cutscenes, which are beautifully rendered, and horribly written. Because of their graphical quality, they interrupt your gameplay with annoying loading screens which can take a minute or more even on a high end PC.Instead of being rewarded for making progress in the game, you are given less opportunities for gameplay. By the end of the game, you unlock amazing tools of destruction and mayham. However, you have also already cleared out all the game's military bases, and are unable to refresh them all at once. Instead you must refresh each individually. This detracts from an immersive experience and leads me to turn to mods to add features I feel are missing.Lastly the DRM is infuriating. If your internet connection is sub par, or if you wish to play offline, the game will periodically interrupt you, pausing your game and attempt to establish an unwanted connection.Just Cause 3 is an awesome game with a few problems so frustrating that they make me hesitate when deciding whether I want to play it again.
