content:
Posted: March 4
												Honestly, I can't recommend this.I'd like to start by explaining that I do like this game. The destruction, the weapons, wingsuiting, crashing planes into bases, it's all a blast, but there are some issues.Despite everything you can do, there's not really that many new things to keep you interested after ~10 hours. Most of the villages are similar and they end up feeling like a chore after a while. The smaller military bases  and oil rigs are also pretty same-y, which usually just ends with you spamming helicopter missiles from afar to get it over with. That being said, it's fun in medium bursts (about 5 hours in a week), but you'll get bored and have to take a break after that.This kind of relates to the previous point, but the map feels a little empty and as a result you'll get bored quick. It's certainly big and there are certainly lots of things in it, but a lot of it still has nothing to do. There are ruins and some structures outside of bases/villages, but at most you'll find a collectible, and usually they're just empty.The upgrades, probably the best addition to the game, are locked behind challenges. This wouldn't be too bad but most of the challenges aren't that great, and there are way too many. Wingsuiting through wings is fun the first 3 times, but 25 times? No thanks. Also, some of the challenges just plain old suck. The driving in the JC games has never been good (in fact, it's pretty bad), so why would I want to do 14 driving challenges? This really hurts the game, because a lot of the upgrades are fun but it feels like a grind to unlock them.The biggest issue of all, the performance. I'm lucky to have a powerful computer, and I can barely run this above 30fps on minimum settings. I know I'm not the only person with these issues, and  I can't imagine someone with a weaker rig being able to run this at all. This is the real nail in the coffin for my recommendation, the game would be passable if people could actually run it, but 5 months and 3 DLC packs later, it doesn't seem like it's going to be fixed any time soon.tl;dr: Game is alright but it fails to add enough new content to keep you invested for a long period of team. This coupled with the horrific performance issues make it a no from me.

content:
Posted: December 1, 2015
												Okay, after some more hours of playing this game I have to say getting past the stuttering, the dropping, and the audio skipping, this game is still really freakin' fun. Just, for the love of explosions, if you want to truely enjoy this game, make sure you meet the minimum requirements.  "But Wrecked, what makes it fun if you are chugging so bad?" Simple, the mechanics. Being able to tether a giant fuel tower to a destroyable concrete wall and then blow them both up so rebels can rush in is one of those moments you cannot get in a game. Wingsuiting from island to island while blowing up bridges to shake off pursuers, not possible in any other game. Being able to pull a boat from the ocean to a garage in town, its a rewarding challange all in it's own.  Just Cause 3 is what Just Cause 2's predecesor should be. It took what it had and made more of it in every way it could. Taking over towns now has a purpose and that's gaining territory and unlocking secret item locations. Challanges give mod parts which is more than an achievement to pin on your Steam profile. Overthrowing towns is just "blow up everything that's red" and not a painfull treasure hunt, and they toss hints your ways towards the end of takeovers for the last few things to blow up because lets be honest, who the hell likes to run around an above ground/undergound base for 20 minutes finding one satelite dish?  Medeci is one giant beautiful playground made just for rage-induced destruction and it does it well, and even when you aren't being Senior McBad***, the game is breath taking. Slow it down, get in a sedan and just drive. Observe the countryside while the spanish guitar strums away at your eardrums. There was love put into this game, and a lot of it. We all just need a little push to fully enjoy it.8/10 It's a damn good game, but those requirements will kill any budget build.Original Review:tl;dr Time to upgrade.   I'm sorry. I really am sorry, but this game is the first game to make my rig outdated. I can run GTA 5 on High, I can run Mad Max on Ultra, and I can run ArmA 3 on Very High. This game has been the first game to make my computer say "Sorry buddy, I can't run this. Have a bowl full of lag." I can understand this being a push to upgrade to some newer better equipment, but as of now I can't give this game a good review.

content:
Posted: March 15
												This is the most fun I've had with a game in a long while.  I generally stay away from third-person shooters, and somehow I missed that this was a third-person game when I bought it.  But after giving it a chance, I can see why the game was made this way -- it really does make for a better experience, and it works well the way it was constructed.I have a pretty new machine, and I am not experiencing any problems playing the game as others have said, except for one thing: my keyboard mapping periodically gets over-written.  (You can solve this by just copying your keyboard map file, so it isn't a huge issue, but I digress.)One very surprising thing about this game for me was how well almost everything in the world blows up.  The physics on destroying things and soldiers really is fun and allows you to use your imagination in your destruction.  At first I didn't like how some things give infinite missiles and bombs, but I think it turns out more fun this way.  I really like that you aren't penalized for destroying civilians, and in some cases it's hilarious ("Rico! You could have just asked for my car!")Once you figure out how to use your cables for destruction and moving around... well, for me there was no turning back!  I'm now in the middle of my second go-around with this game, and still having loads of fun with it.  I definitely recommend: Get this game.

content:
Posted: December 30, 2015
Summary:A seemingly common issue, this explosion-filled open world action-adventure's fairly severe performance issues on some systems can be fixed by forcing /borderless /fullscreen in the game's Steam command line. Despite its fairly poor optimisation and forced online, this game took Just Cause 2 and improved on many of that game's aspects, especially in terms of visuals and game mechanics (most notably the wingsuit), and as such, it's a fun title to play around with for a while. Yet gameplay outside the story quickly becomes repetitive and lacklustre, and the flawed Rebel Drop system severely limits the player from creativity, particularly early-game. As such, this game is only worth the price when on sale, and Just Cause 2 will undoubtedly give more entertainment in the long-term - for a much lower price.Rating:1 - A masterpiece. An essential purchase for everyone.2 - Great game. Highly recommended to most people.3 - Fairly good game. Recommended mainly for fans of the genre or when on sale.4 - Poor game. Not recommended but has a few merits.5 - Awful game. Would not recommend to anyone in their right minds.

content:
Posted: January 7, 2016
												So far have spent 25 hrs in this game, beat the story @ 20 hrs. This is the first Just Cause I have played, also my setup is an i5 4590, gtx 970 ssc, 8GB ram, HDD, 1080p monitor. Have a few pro's and cons I want to mention.ProSuper fun as far as just causing pure havoc with a wide variety of tools. (hehe, "just causing")Good variety of side challengesGood variety of weapons from pistols/rifles/rpgs/nuke launchersWingsuit/tethering/parachute mechanic is great, easy to get use to. Makes it really fun getting around the map in the early stages.I particularly enjoyed the leaderboard aspect of the game, whenever it popped up I took it as a small challenge; however, I have good internet, so I can see where that might be a con to some even though the game does offer an offline mode.Settlements can be taken over using a variety of tactics, from lots of explosions and guns, to lots of tethering and flying around.Relatively large map.ConTake-overs are very cookie cutter. The only challenge is the number of chaos objects you have to destroy to get the base/settlement. Once you know how to neutralise the defenses, you pretty much control how challenging you want it to be.Vehicles are very OP, once you get ahold of something with a cannon/missiles, you're pretty much invincible if you learn how to drive it.You navigate 3 islands. 2 pretty small, 1 freaking enormous one. The giant island makes wingsuiting seem pretty slow after getting use to it for the previous locations.This game is moderately buggy. When exiting from challenges sometimes the screen will freeze until I hit the default exit button (ctrl). I experience ghosting during cutscenes and moderate frames drops/stuttering after ~1 hr. Vehicle controls are wonky. Planes rotate around the camera view and don't allow for good mouse control. Key mapping between helicopter/plane is independent except for one area, weapons. Found this out the hard way when I blew myself up upon taking off in a helicopter.Unnecessary total score system. (You blew up a tank! Yay here's some points that go to absolutely nothing!)Gear upgrades are assigned to certain challenges. (i.e. If you want to upgrade your tethers to the max, you better learn how to drive a vehicle well...with people shooting at you. Want more ammo for your RPG? Get more accurate with your pistols. Want to order more than one air drop? Learn how to fly.)Story missions are fun, plot is useless, but they need to be completed to get past certain points on the map.Has a lot of filler mechanics/challenges (i.e. sanctuary, shrines, tapes)OverallI would recommend this game to others. I got it on the winter sale for ~$40 which I would say is a fair price. The open sandbox still allows me to play it after beating it the story so I can still blow stuff up to my hearts content with greater and greater weapons.8/10 would dive into the side of a cliff again.

content:
Posted: November 29, 2016
												This game is unique in that not only do you fight the army named DRM that is ruling over the ficticious country you are liberating, you will also be fighting the DRM code in the game that rules over your play experience. If you can't get connected to square enix's terrible servers, the game will forcefully pause the game every single time you check your map, start a mission, end a mission, or do anything remotely related to the UI so it can re-attempt to log you in for who the ♥♥♥♥ knows what reason. My guess is that competing with people online over scores such as most distance reeled in a single reel, most headshots in a row, and most explosions in X time period was so important to the game that the developers decided that everything else must be periodically halted so that these magnificient scores can be updated.If you are lucky enough not to have issues with the DRM, rest assured, there are other issues with the game. The controls for this game seem to be tailored especially for console users as moving the mouse around to look summons some sort of acceleration that is commonly used in games to assist console users as the control stick can't look around nearly as fast as a mouse can. This also seems to be the case when driving as when making a turn the car has some sort of lag effect before turning. Most of the time this causes an overshoot of the desired direction and then you need to steer the opposite direction which causes a rinse and repeat effect of overshooting again because no vehicle in the world operates like this at speeds less than 10mph.

												This is the most fun I've had with a game in a long while.  I generally stay away from third-person shooters, and somehow I missed that this was a third-person game when I bought it.  But after giving it a chance, I can see why the game was made this way -- it really does make for a better experience, and it works well the way it was constructed.I have a pretty new machine, and I am not experiencing any problems playing the game as others have said, except for one thing: my keyboard mapping periodically gets over-written.  (You can solve this by just copying your keyboard map file, so it isn't a huge issue, but I digress.)One very surprising thing about this game for me was how well almost everything in the world blows up.  The physics on destroying things and soldiers really is fun and allows you to use your imagination in your destruction.  At first I didn't like how some things give infinite missiles and bombs, but I think it turns out more fun this way.  I really like that you aren't penalized for destroying civilians, and in some cases it's hilarious ("Rico! You could have just asked for my car!")Once you figure out how to use your cables for destruction and moving around... well, for me there was no turning back!  I'm now in the middle of my second go-around with this game, and still having loads of fun with it.  I definitely recommend: Get this game.

content:
Posted: March 5
How much I recommend the gameI would only recommend this game if you really know what you're getting yourself into. I marked "Yes" because It was a fun game to play and I'm familiar with the series. While the game had its fair share of problems, if you're a fan of the series you'll enjoy yourself. Unfortunately, in my opinion, it is a downgrade from the sequel. If there was a "mixed" option, I would probably choose that instead. I purchased this game while it was 75% off, and I highly recommend that you do the same if you really want it.PerformanceIf you have a high end system, don't worry about the people complaining about memory leaks.I have 16GB RAM, GTX 1070, and Intel 6700k and experienced no real issues regarding memory leaks.However, that does not change the fact that the game was very glitchy. Enemies spawn in right before your eyes at times, physics glitches are not uncommon, and the game is generally unstable (in the lovable Just Cause sort of way). I will still able to maintain a consistently high frame rate despite this. I have crashed to desktop 1 time, and had to force close the game due to it locking up 2 times in my 24 hours of playing it, so it's really not all that bad.GameplayDrivingThey somehow managed to make the driving even worse than how it was in Just Cause 2. Once you get used to it, it's not so bad. Motorcycles are especially horrible to drive, you will never get used to them. The vehicles have a really strange momentum/weight to them, and it's very difficult to drive with a keyboard and mouse unlike in games like Grand Theft Auto 5 or Saint's Row. The driving mechanics also depend way too much on using your hand brake, and of course that is a pain since the controls are frustrating. Be prepared to not use your space bar for hand brakes. They also got rid of the Stunt Jump mechanic from Just Cause 2, which is a major disappointment. It's a lot harder to hijack cars and vehicles, and it's very frustrating trying to enter cars via grappling hook alone. Rico also has a very cool habit of only walking while on boats and planes. Since there is no more Stunt Jumping, this makes it very tedious and frustrating to actually enter the cockpit of boats and planes. In Just Cause 2, you could just press the Stunt Jump button to have Rico quickly and automatically grapple his way into position to enter a vehicle and drive it, but in 3 you have to actually walk over to the cockpit or car door for some reason.KeybindingThis game was clearly not optimized for PC. The game will never let you know about keybind conflicts, and with so many different keys and functions, things get very difficult to manage. I actually ended up binding "contract tether" to one of the rudder controls for air vehicles by accident and realized this halfway through the game. The game will also not let you know if chaning one bind for one control will change another. For example, if you want to change your parachute button while on foot to something else, this will in turn change your parachute and bail buttons for driving as well, and the game will not notify you of this. Also, there are many binds that are linked, such as jumping onto the roof of a car and bailing by parachute. The game will list these as separate binds although they will always be bound to the same button no matter what. This was one of the biggest annoyances of this game. The keybinding in Just Cause 2 was leagues better than this.General GameplayIt's repetitive, but such is the nature of Just Cause. However, since the story is lackluster, none of it really feels like it's worth it. Sure, it's fun to destroy bases and liberate towns at first, but then you start to realize the copy/paste nature of many areas in the game world, and the game starts turning into a chore. There are also many annoying parts of combat. Enemies with shotguns can temporarily stun Rico from quite long ranges for some reason. Also, hitting the ground while using a wingsuit is very annoying. No matter how fast you go, Rico will get stunned, unless you unlock the ability to retract your wingsuit when going slowly near the ground, which should have been a feature by default. Be sure not to get stunned while on a mountain or something, or else Rico will go into an uncontrollable tumble for an annoyingly long amount of time. The stun mechanics in the game are horrible and annoying. You will find yourself getting frustrated every time Rico falls over.There are also many challenges that you must do to upgrade tools and equipment, which also (surprise!) gets annoying quite quickly. By doing challenges, you earn "gears" which act as currency towards upgrades of different kinds. If you do a racing challenge you unlock gears for cars, gun challenges unlock gears for guns, and so forth. You actually have to unlock things like precision aiming, which should have been available from the beginning by default, and things like increased tethers, which should have been unlocked as the story progressed. A lot of the unlocks are also very underwhelming and were clearly meant to be filler/padding for the more interesting and useful upgrades. Oh, I unlocked the ability to get a supply drop faster? Wow, because they were sooo slow to begin with.StoryThe story was pretty nice, but the ending felt incredibly rushed. Things will be developing at a certain pace and then it will ramp up out of nowhere and end unexpectedly. The ending is unbelievably underwhelming compared to the ending of Just Cause 2. Spoilers: You don't end up fistfighting Baby Panay while riding a nuke. The game also lacks the charm of Just Cause 2. Just Cause 2 felt like a campy B-movie, and Rico felt like the stereotypical lead to that kind of movie, his voice actor fit the role perfectly. You could practically see him doing the sign of the cross after taking out baddies. Now, Rico is this rugged manly man with a new voice actor whom I'm not entirely fond of. Rico is still Rico, though. He's still out fighting for the greater good and trying to end corruption, taking the obvious moral high ground as always, and I love him for it. Just Cause 3 story-wise is basically Just Cause 2, but with less of the B-movie charm. It is nice to finally get some answers regarding Rico's past, as well as somewhat of a conclusion to it. I really enjoyed the setting and premise of the story, but felt that it was lacking in a few areas.ConclusionIf you want to just kill time with a game revolving around mindless action and chaos, and dont mind the occasional glitch and can stand mediocre controls, then go for it. It was fun to play but it could have been a lot better. If you haven't played Just Cause 2, I would HIGHLY recommend that you do before playing 3, it'll make you appreciate 3 a lot more.

content:
Posted: December 31, 2015
												I did not experience technical issues.  I did experience a somewhat bland, but somewhat hilarious, sandbox game that fills a unique niche in the sandbox universe.  To be fair, I can't even remember its prequel to compare it to, because it, too, must have had the same flaws.This game is all about the grapple and stunts.  You can do a lot of fun, memorable stuff.  But, because of some design decisions and flaws, the gameplay doesn't feel spectacular or worthy of re-playing.1. The controls are not polished enough.  This is something most open-world games have a problem with, but when you're gliding and grappling around it's a huge pain point.  I found myself swearing as I flew into walls or got stuck under ledges.2. When you die, you just respawn where you left off. So you can basically liberate the whole map before doing any missions.3. New enemies spawn behind from all sides, making battles chaotic and not strategic in any way. This negates any use of the sniper rifle.4. Because of the lack of battle tactics, Rico is almost invincible, and so they didn't include crouching or cover because of this and the above point.5. Upgrades (or 'mods' as they call them) are mostly optional. They help a little, but not enough to make the game easier or feel rewarding.6. Most of the time, it was easier to glide/parachute/fast-travel rather than find a vehicle. Traveling got to be quite a shlep in the mountains.  The vehicles and attention to their detail are amazing but mostly superfluous.These points together contributed to a loss of enjoyment in gameplay.A typical attack on a military base involves parachuting around haphazardly and shooting missiles at targets.  This could have been much more fun if there were a stealth element, or 'level up' health/abilities before attempting, or both.The story has a lot of interesting characters who are never fully fleshed out.  Some side-missions with them would have been fun, or at least some more back-story.  I think maybe I was supposed to remember them from a previous game?Overall, the game is beautiful and fun, to an extent. The story isnt bad, but there's not enough of it to be fulfilling.  There is little replay value and gameplay gets repetitive quickly.  I'm left wishing I could go back into sandbox mode and have a good romp, but everything's liberated, and the battles weren't that fun to begin with.

												Alright, I have played this game for about 44 hours  and have to say it's a nice game if you like blowing stuff up and causing chaos and destruction. the map is insanely big but it's fun to have a map this huge, lot of things to explore, outposts to liberate, destroying entire airports and what not.There are a lot of collectibles to collect and I'd say if you really hunt em down (like I did) you probably have to spend about 5 to 7 hours in total to collect everything (used the fast travel a LOT) and you get nice stuff when you collect every collectible from a certain category, such as all Di ravelio's tapes or ancient tombs.Now this game is awesome, but there are a lot of things that do bug me. mostly known by now are the FPS drops, they are not that common, I'd say they are rare, at least for me (may depend on how beefy your pc is, I can say my pc exceeds the recommended system requirements by far so it doesn't bother me that much but still).Frequent crashes have made me (literally) smash my headset, when you're in the middle of a mission, and it happends to be a quite difficult one and you crash of all the sudden, you (or I at least) can get quite mad. especially if you have to take another route to avoid the point were it crashes your game every single time.Something else is the lock on feature in fighter jets, you have to disable the MOD (don't know the exact name rn) that let you aim better and restart your game before you can actually use lock on. something like that should not happen at all, I had to restart the mission where you have to protect Rosa Manuela's plane more than 10 times because of a not working lock on.All this seems like this game is bugged af, but it's not entirely. at the beginning it's difficult getting the hang of the new controls (especially going back with 'CTRL') and getting used to face planting 24/7. but after a while when you unlock new weapons and MODs for your tools, it gets soo much more fun. I personally am obsessed with the M488, a ♥♥♥♥ing rocket launcher, infused with bavarium to make your rockets go off like bloody nukes. I never had so much fun in any game before as I had with the M488.If you're into blowing up stuff hardcore, ready to die quite often (because of how hard it sometimes can be) and wanna wingsuit like a badass, and can deal with sudden fps drops. I highly recommend this game for you. if not, go and find another game where you can cause the same amount of destruction and still have fun

content:
Posted: August 10, 2016
												Written from the point of view of someone who has played 123 hours of Just Cause 2 and would probably rank it in my top 5 games.JC3 is pretty fun. Pretty all as expected. It looks fantastic. I really like the better implemented destruction. Driving is feels a lot better than JC2. Being able to see on the map the things you need to destroy to complete a settlement is a life saver. Having unlimited plantable bombs makes a long session of destruction easier and means you don't mind using your rocket launcher or similar weapon more. The progression is more interesting than JC3 with you getting more abilities rather than just weapon hits harder. Couldn't imagine life without the wing suit now. But the main missions are dull af, very few highlights. Its mostly just 'escort' missions where you have to protect something, so its just adding a rule holding back your destructions. Just Cause 2's location feels more interesting than Medici; it has as snow, desert, forests, mountains and huge cities where medici only has forests, mountains, coastline (very pretty) and quarry areas. The challenges are pretty dull; Wing suit ones are alright but the destruction ones are again just adding rules to limit how you want to play. It feels like its missing one extra variable to really vary things up. And I'm not just talking about co op, but that would have been a great addition. JC3 is more of the same with a few improvements. If you found JC2 repetitive you probably won't get a lot out of JC3. For some reason I don't think I'll keep coming back like I did for JC2. So overall I did have a fair amount of fun with JC3, but it didn't blow my socks off as I was hoping.

Posted: March 7, 2016
												When I first booted the game, I had countless problems, from the uncanny crashing to the horrendous framerate, and thankfully I managed to get everything fixed. The game is absolutely superb, and that is just because it is fun. A fun game is mostly what you need, and a game may have a decent story, but if it isn't fun, then it isn't worth playing. This game exceeds on what Just Cause 2 build, and makes an experience that is basically Michael Bay simulator on drugs. Unfortunately, there are a few problems, like not being able to kinda zoom in with your weapon as well as not having the ability to sprint. These elements should be key in a game like this, but unfortunately no. Also, the game doesn't have a mini map so it makes things a bit difficult at specific times. The side missions are pretty much just liberating and races. Thankfully, they are both fun. The car handling isn't particularly amazing, but I guess it works. The graphics are pretty good, especially Rico's character model.The world is GORGEOUS. It is massive, exotic and beautiful. The music is also really nice. The combat is good fun, but it feels pretty much like every other game and it is far, far too easy for me. Either way, I love it and I can't put it down! The story though, is particularly uninteresting but the characters are really nice. I cannot wait for the multiplayer mod anyway. This is a must buy if you can get it on a sale! It is lengthy and a great purchase.

content:
Posted: April 4, 2016
												If it's >=75% off, you have the money to spend and really enjoy Just Cause, sure.I bought this game during the Christmas sale at 20% off ($47.99 US) and have enjoyed my purchase, though I wish I'd waited for a deeper sale.PROS: - It's really fun in freeroam- The story is the best out of the series (e.g. terrible but enjoyable campy)- Avalanche knows the strengths of the series, so you're powerful but so is the AI- The wingsuit is a great addition- Nuke launcher- Tanks and helicopters with shields- It's amazing how good it is considering the ♥♥♥♥♥♥ business practices- Great graphics, nice aesthetic- Plenty of easter eggs- Amazing explosionsNEUTRAL: - A lot of weapons are gated behind missions- Acceptable performance: Was above 50 fps 99% of the time, which is good for me, on a 980 (keep in mind my monitor is connected via HDMI so it's locked to 60) with every setting except AA maxed. Did see some stuttering in high-foliage environments like forests, but that's expected for me. CONS: - One save slot. On PC. Really.- ♥♥♥♥♥♥ always-online DRM (ironic because the enemy is called the DRM)- Most side missions to unlock gear mods are super boring*- Enemies can be bullet sponges- Buggy**- Moderately high pop-in- The volcano in the game does not have a base inside it- Load times in the 5-10 minute range, thanks to the before-mentioned always-online DRM- Once you complete the game, you must manually "re-oppress" every base seperately. And you need to teleport to that base to do it, which can take upwards of 30 seconds. Don't expect to easily have a new game plus run without save editing.*The wingsuit courses are fun, the gun range is super easy if you have a mouse, the rest are just annoying because you almost get x stars but are just off**I've noticed at least four bugs:-If you go at high enough velocity downwards, you go through the ground and have to swim to the coast, underground- Helicopters can instantly die if their rotors clip something because the rotors apparently have the mass of the whole helicopter- If you have precision aim (which is an unlockable upgrade, for some reason) on, missiles don't lock on. A patch tried to fix this, but it's still broken for me. This means you can't complete certain missions without restarting the game.- A ♥♥♥♥ton of flickeringNOTESThere's ~5-10 minutes of loading before starting the game. Probably an hour or two of my 'playtime' was loading, especially considering it sometimes didn't connect and so reconnected everytime I paused or opened a menu. This is in service of a leaderboard which is interesting but which doesn't justify the connection times or lack of an offline mode. You can physically unplug your internet or disconnect your computer, but it still attempts connection on every loading screen, even if you're offline on Steam. It's a testament to this game that I was able to still enjoy and recommend it. Also, I played it with the default version which did not include any DLC and I beat the campaign and liberated every base in 36 hours, which included significant ♥♥♥♥ing around.

content:
Posted: December 31, 2015
												I did not experience technical issues.  I did experience a somewhat bland, but somewhat hilarious, sandbox game that fills a unique niche in the sandbox universe.  To be fair, I can't even remember its prequel to compare it to, because it, too, must have had the same flaws.This game is all about the grapple and stunts.  You can do a lot of fun, memorable stuff.  But, because of some design decisions and flaws, the gameplay doesn't feel spectacular or worthy of re-playing.1. The controls are not polished enough.  This is something most open-world games have a problem with, but when you're gliding and grappling around it's a huge pain point.  I found myself swearing as I flew into walls or got stuck under ledges.2. When you die, you just respawn where you left off. So you can basically liberate the whole map before doing any missions.3. New enemies spawn behind from all sides, making battles chaotic and not strategic in any way. This negates any use of the sniper rifle.4. Because of the lack of battle tactics, Rico is almost invincible, and so they didn't include crouching or cover because of this and the above point.5. Upgrades (or 'mods' as they call them) are mostly optional. They help a little, but not enough to make the game easier or feel rewarding.6. Most of the time, it was easier to glide/parachute/fast-travel rather than find a vehicle. Traveling got to be quite a shlep in the mountains.  The vehicles and attention to their detail are amazing but mostly superfluous.These points together contributed to a loss of enjoyment in gameplay.A typical attack on a military base involves parachuting around haphazardly and shooting missiles at targets.  This could have been much more fun if there were a stealth element, or 'level up' health/abilities before attempting, or both.The story has a lot of interesting characters who are never fully fleshed out.  Some side-missions with them would have been fun, or at least some more back-story.  I think maybe I was supposed to remember them from a previous game?Overall, the game is beautiful and fun, to an extent. The story isnt bad, but there's not enough of it to be fulfilling.  There is little replay value and gameplay gets repetitive quickly.  I'm left wishing I could go back into sandbox mode and have a good romp, but everything's liberated, and the battles weren't that fun to begin with.

content:
Posted: April 4, 2016
												If it's >=75% off, you have the money to spend and really enjoy Just Cause, sure.I bought this game during the Christmas sale at 20% off ($47.99 US) and have enjoyed my purchase, though I wish I'd waited for a deeper sale.PROS: - It's really fun in freeroam- The story is the best out of the series (e.g. terrible but enjoyable campy)- Avalanche knows the strengths of the series, so you're powerful but so is the AI- The wingsuit is a great addition- Nuke launcher- Tanks and helicopters with shields- It's amazing how good it is considering the ♥♥♥♥♥♥ business practices- Great graphics, nice aesthetic- Plenty of easter eggs- Amazing explosionsNEUTRAL: - A lot of weapons are gated behind missions- Acceptable performance: Was above 50 fps 99% of the time, which is good for me, on a 980 (keep in mind my monitor is connected via HDMI so it's locked to 60) with every setting except AA maxed. Did see some stuttering in high-foliage environments like forests, but that's expected for me. CONS: - One save slot. On PC. Really.- ♥♥♥♥♥♥ always-online DRM (ironic because the enemy is called the DRM)- Most side missions to unlock gear mods are super boring*- Enemies can be bullet sponges- Buggy**- Moderately high pop-in- The volcano in the game does not have a base inside it- Load times in the 5-10 minute range, thanks to the before-mentioned always-online DRM- Once you complete the game, you must manually "re-oppress" every base seperately. And you need to teleport to that base to do it, which can take upwards of 30 seconds. Don't expect to easily have a new game plus run without save editing.*The wingsuit courses are fun, the gun range is super easy if you have a mouse, the rest are just annoying because you almost get x stars but are just off**I've noticed at least four bugs:-If you go at high enough velocity downwards, you go through the ground and have to swim to the coast, underground- Helicopters can instantly die if their rotors clip something because the rotors apparently have the mass of the whole helicopter- If you have precision aim (which is an unlockable upgrade, for some reason) on, missiles don't lock on. A patch tried to fix this, but it's still broken for me. This means you can't complete certain missions without restarting the game.- A ♥♥♥♥ton of flickeringNOTESThere's ~5-10 minutes of loading before starting the game. Probably an hour or two of my 'playtime' was loading, especially considering it sometimes didn't connect and so reconnected everytime I paused or opened a menu. This is in service of a leaderboard which is interesting but which doesn't justify the connection times or lack of an offline mode. You can physically unplug your internet or disconnect your computer, but it still attempts connection on every loading screen, even if you're offline on Steam. It's a testament to this game that I was able to still enjoy and recommend it. Also, I played it with the default version which did not include any DLC and I beat the campaign and liberated every base in 36 hours, which included significant ♥♥♥♥ing around.

												I had no issues running this on my rig (GTX 1060 6GB, Intel Core i5 6500, 8GB of ram). The gameplay is improved over JC2 through many minor tweaks to various aspects. It feels less clunky and less restrictive than the previous game. The story is still pretty weak and predictable. The upgrade system is nice however the challenges are pretty meh. The way to unlock more abilities and thus improve your character is to succeed at random minigames dispersed throughout the map with no context. These challenges tend to be like fun little arcade games but they can get repetitive and occasionally frustrating. I personally dislike how far removed these things are from the rest of the game. Driving a car through hoops really fast doesn't feel at all connected to the goal of removing a dictatorship. I would still recommend this game because the open world feels like a better Just Cause 2 and it is fun to mess around with the civilians. I'd say pick it up when it's at $15 if you have a solid computer and enjoyed Just Cause 2.

												Just Cause 3 got a lot of hate when it came out in December for being extremely laggy and barely working. If I wrote this review then, I'd say something along the lines of "Don't get this game until they fix it". And guess what? They did. By the time I got around to playing it, I was getting a smooth 60 fps everywhere with one GTX 970.Pros:-It's mental. Bases that fire nukes and pretty much everything in bases are physics objects-Jets on the two airports respawn INSTANTLY. No waiting around for them to respawn-Its very pretty-By the end of the game, you'll be practically an immortal god because of the upgrades you can get-You don't have to do the story. I ran off and destroyed every base that I could find and unlocked the perks that make Rico amazing-There are sheilded tanks and helicopters, my personal favorite for destruction-The wingsuit is the BEST way to travel in any game. They nailed the grapple/wingsuit combo-You can turn the SAM's on the enemies. Cons:-Story is a bit bland, Just Cause 2's story was MUCH better-Rebel drops and their stupid wait times. (You can disable this by doing the races, but still, 10 minutes for a gun? No thanks)-Rebel drops are limited. You have to travel to a garage to pick up more rebel beacons.Overall, I recommend this game a lot but I'd avoid the story at first

content:
Posted: March 12
												Pour in a tin :•1 full mixing bowl of explosions•10 tall tablespoons of fun•2 glasses of sumptuous graphics•A pinch of craziness•As many experiments as you wantMix everything.Bake in the oven at 400 ºF for several thousand hours.Serve with your friends and enjoy.Just Cause 3 is an open-world, destruction, fun simulator. You can literally do whatever you want in this game. It has so many possibilities that you never get bored of it! I have played it a few hours and still don't have explored all. A lot of people say it's a Michael Bay Simulator... Indeed, it is! The giant explosions; sometimes "Just Caused" by a simple flick, will let you AGAPE! You can choose to follow the story of the campaign, which I think is really cool and entertaining, or you can choose to spend your time exploring the majestic, giant and beautiful world.The graphics? They are just amazing. I have rarely seen graphics that nice in other games... (I've made so many screenshots in the game to remember all the delicious places I've met...) You also have a menu to spawn weapons and vehicles where you want on the map. The tall choice of this menu is very pleasant. From the bike to the giant army plane, going through the assault tank! Also, the wingsuit and the grapple system is something you can only find in Just Cause... It's one of the most important gadget in the game, allowing you to go everywhere on the map with much fun!The only thing that is missing yet, is a multiplayer mode. Sharing with your friends your crazy experimentations and funny nonsenses is something very pleasant. Just Cause 2 multiplayer mode was much fun... Bring it back, developers! By the way, you will have to play it with a good computer, otherwise the graphics will not be as beautiful as I said, and it will crash many times if you get too crazy with your experimentations!Finally, if you want a game that never bores you and where you can have much fun, playing an entire day, stop looking for it. This game is Just Cause 3.

content:
Posted: December 4, 2015
												Well worth the wait, well worth the money!I had purchased this all the way back to May, after spending continuous weeks on JC2. This one is just as good, with better and worse parts.Better than JC2:+Graphics. Not perfect, but great. Could be better? Yes. Would that be necessary? No. Its good enough. It's great. I liked the optimization too. Worked almost fluent in all very high settings on my GTX860M Acer Nitro (Most people are having optimization and performance issues though).+The wingsuit. Ah, what a pleasure. I hope they consider putting this to JC2 as a mod. It changes the whole game.+Physics engine and the new wire tethering. With just a little experience, the need for guns is gone. And it doesn't get boring that fast. Very fun to play with.+Environments. With better graphics, better views. +New capturing system. No more "just kill everything". Still, these are just to keep things from being the same thing over and over again, for a while.+Loading times. The game loads while you watch the intros. And it does not take a very long time too. But you WILL need an SSD to stop nagging about it. Worse than JC2:-Controls. The steering delay is even worse, gun controls were better IMO.-Staying online all the time. Not mandatory, but keeps trying to compare achievements and annoys at times.-HUD. Minimap is gone, so are most of the object indicators.-Cutscenes are choppy. But, then again, it might just be my configuration.-Map and menu. They found a way to make the map even less functional, and more important.-Random glitches and crashes. Everyone's having different problems. Most people have performance issues too.Now, JC3 is great. It might suck where JC2 made its fame (optimization, controls) but it's still a lot fun to play. If you have not tried JC2, I suggest you give it a try first. They are basically the same.I can't help feeling that Just Cause 3 is an unfinished game. It feels like they had a couple more things to add but they reached the deadline. It could be better, eventhough it's already worth the money.

content:
Posted: December 3, 2015
												Ridiculously broken at the moment for me, (R9 270X & Athlon 750K  8GB RAM) but tuns at a decent framerate. Only like half the worlds polygons load in.But I've played 10+ hrs like that and enjoyed all of it so it's quite good to me. It's essentially and updated JC2, more refined and some cool new things added.I reccomend the game, assuming that AMD/Avalanche get it together and patch the issues.12/20/15:Both AMD and avalanche released patches, and the game functions normally now, runs pretty well on my rig with settings somwhere between medium and high. Loading times are not so great for me however, I have the game stored on a 7200 RPM SATA drive, and I usually have to load for about a minute for everything, except the initial startup, which is more like 4 minutes. Not a huge deal, but it seems like the kind of problem an older game would have.Just beat the story and liberated everything, except for 3 settlements that I can't find, and don't seem to belong to a province.I can say I enjoyed the game, and I would reccomend it, however for 60$, I don't feel the content is diverse enough for the price. Each town you liberate is pretty much the same, there are a few types of military bases, but not many. There are so many of these that it kind of becomes a chore, and more so once you figure out how to destroy stuff the easiest.Another issue; in JC2, my favorite part was foing to and from missions, which isn't the case in this game, because my favorite way to get around was by eingsuit and fast travel, since the driving physics were bizzare to me. While you're in the air, the only things that makes traveling interesting are trees and mountains. By interesting I mostly mean difficult. As a whole however, I quite liked wingsuiting around Medici.As many people talked about around release time, the game world is huge, but the content is just spread out, making it somewhat artificially large. This doesn't bother me a whole lot, considering it's more reason to use the wingsuit, but it was something that I definately noticed throughout the game. Story is aggressively mediocre, but it didn't bother me at all. Everything is cheesy and over the top, whih is fun, but don't expect anything to wow you or interest you greatly.Graphics are fanastic, possibly the nicest looking game I've played, considering not jsut textures and polygons, but colors and art. Very pretty game.Overall I'd give it a hearty recomendation if you're willing to grind through liberatiing everything, and if you don't mind a cheesy story.

Posted: March 9, 2016
												After playing Just Cause 2 on the Playstation 3 for many many hours, it's a little disappointing that I can't recommend this game to anyone, at least in the state it's in. Months after release, I thought enough updates would have passed and made the game how it should have been at launch. Ha, no. I have an i5 processor, GTX 970 (which is actually the card recommended for the best experience on this game) and 8GB of RAM, and yet I can't run this game at the settings I should be able to without getting the worst framerate I've ever had to experience. At launch, I was able to fiddle around and make it work reasonably well, but come on. This game is months old and I still can't play it without nerfing the settings. And even when the settings were lowered it wasn't perfect. As a result, I can't judge this game for it's merits. The unplayable choppy framerate (which gets worse with the more action) has left such a bad taste in my mouth that I can't look at the good points of this game without being annoyed. I've looked up fixes, made sure all my drivers are up to date, but I can no longer be bothered to look for ways to fix something that SHOULD NOT NEED FIXING. I'm not going to re-install my drivers or go into the game's files or whatever, 99% of other games don't require me to do this and I'm certainly not going to start now with this one. Just Cause 3 will sit in my library, Steam will download it's updates automatically, and I will wait and see. And the longer it takes Avalanche to get it together, the more likely I won't buy anything they make in the future. From a disappointed fan.

content:
Posted: July 20, 2016
												Why should you buy this game. Just Cause. Ok got that out of the way. Just Cause 3 is a open-world sandbox psychopath simulator where you fill the nitroglicerin filled shoes of Rico Rodrigez: professional dictator remover. No really that's his job title. Just Cause 3 is all about exploring a very beatiful series of islands and liberating them from a powerhungry despot by blowing them to oblivion. Liberate! The core gameplay revolves entirely around blowing stuff up and doing it with style. The entire sandbox is built around that design system and if you are looking for a more story driven experience then you better continue looking because this isn't your game. With that said I have adress the elephant in the room: that game has some notable technical issues that have made the game borderline unplayable for some people. I can run it pretty well on medium settings with some framerate drops when I'm blowing a military base into the stratosphere but so far there hasn't been any outright gamebreaking framedrops (My laptop uses a Nvidia 780M and I have 32GB of RAM). With that said if you don't have a decent video card and at least 12 GB of RAM I'd suggest holding off buying JC3. But if you have required specs the you should go for it.

content:
Posted: August 21, 2016
												I'm going to say it straight foward, this game is incredible if you have the rig to run it.People are knocking this game because of its inferior performance to games like GTAV and MGSV, which are slower paced games. This game moves fast, and your game will move slow if your computer is slow a snail.  So if you have a sub-par computer that does not meet the recommended requirements. Put this game in the wish list, becuase it is damn well worth it when you have a rig that can properly run it  (My GTX 960 and Haswell I7 run it at a crystal clear 60fps with ultra settings (AA at MSAA 4x)). Is this game perfect? No, it is not perfect. The main story is not the crux of the show, it comes in the form of the town clearing and the challenges. This game shoots itself in the foot by hampering a ridiculous amount of your power through the upgrade system, so while you are playing the game, do the challenges. No, you might not get 5 stars initially, but the upgrades are worth the effort. When you have even semi-maxed tethers and grenades, the♥♥♥♥♥♥you can do is so much fun that it's worth it.I do have to say that the wingsuit was the most frustrating part for me in terms of challenges. Not because of the variety and beautiful vistas that they take you through, but because of how poorly the wingsuit handled for me initially. Unfortunately, I have only a mouse and keyboard, but you can actually master the wingsuit with mouse and keyboard. If you tap the keys rapidly to do your maneuvers, you won't have your movement locked and faceplant into the ground. Just a piece of advice from me to you.To those who say the DLC is too short, I understand where you're coming from, but do not forget that the idea is to combine them and use them in the main game. And holy♥♥♥♥♥♥ it is really fun to go through Montagne and the mines with the DLC content. I would suggest playing through the vanilla content by itself initially, but the DLC content provided me an extra 25 hours of gameplay just by screwing around with the weapons that the DLC provide. Did I mention that the OST is amazing? The game feels so great with headphones while you blowing people to shreds. The game's appeal is not from using amazing gadgets, this is not your average Ubisoft open-world. It is a crazy game that will  NOT  hold your hand at baby dumb mode. You can't move around and kill easily on foot? No♥♥♥♥♥♥ the name of the game is to fly around and blow♥♥♥♥♥♥up from the skies with your parachute and gadgets. You can beat the game by simply hitting♥♥♥♥♥♥with the gun on ground, but this is a classic Eidos game. There's more depth to it that you expect.It took me 95 hours to 100% this game over winter break, and it was one of the greatest times I've ever had with a game. If you have the rig to run it and the patience to get good at it, you will not regret it at all.

content:
Posted: August 10, 2016
												Written from the point of view of someone who has played 123 hours of Just Cause 2 and would probably rank it in my top 5 games.JC3 is pretty fun. Pretty all as expected. It looks fantastic. I really like the better implemented destruction. Driving is feels a lot better than JC2. Being able to see on the map the things you need to destroy to complete a settlement is a life saver. Having unlimited plantable bombs makes a long session of destruction easier and means you don't mind using your rocket launcher or similar weapon more. The progression is more interesting than JC3 with you getting more abilities rather than just weapon hits harder. Couldn't imagine life without the wing suit now. But the main missions are dull af, very few highlights. Its mostly just 'escort' missions where you have to protect something, so its just adding a rule holding back your destructions. Just Cause 2's location feels more interesting than Medici; it has as snow, desert, forests, mountains and huge cities where medici only has forests, mountains, coastline (very pretty) and quarry areas. The challenges are pretty dull; Wing suit ones are alright but the destruction ones are again just adding rules to limit how you want to play. It feels like its missing one extra variable to really vary things up. And I'm not just talking about co op, but that would have been a great addition. JC3 is more of the same with a few improvements. If you found JC2 repetitive you probably won't get a lot out of JC3. For some reason I don't think I'll keep coming back like I did for JC2. So overall I did have a fair amount of fun with JC3, but it didn't blow my socks off as I was hoping.

Not Suitable For High End Gaming PCs If you have a high end gaming PC then I recommend that you avoid this game (even if you LOVED Just Cause 2), because there is a good chance that you won't be able to play it. JC3 will not run on my PC. And when I was searching through forums trying to get the game to work, I discovered that I am not the only person having this problem (game crashes immediately after you jump off the plane at the beginning).I'm running a liquid-cooled Core i7 5930k at 4.5 GHz, on an Asus Rampage V Edition 10, with 16 GB memory and dual 980 Ti video cards in SLI. Also, just FYI, I have tried *everything* to get JC3 working, including clocking everything back down to stock speeds and voltages, and using low graphics settings in-game, and removing 1 of the video cards. No luck.JC2 was an awesome game (despite the bugs in the PC version), and if the developer had bothered to put some time/money into supporting JC3 after its PC release, then JC could have gone on to become a huge title in the future. But, unfortunately for them (and for PC gamers), their developers are lazy (or understaffed/underfunded) and their QA staff is incompetent, so that is unlikely to happen... unless the developer decides to start investing in the title immediately (e.g. release updates to support high end PC hardware configurations).

Summary:A seemingly common issue, this explosion-filled open world action-adventure's fairly severe performance issues on some systems can be fixed by forcing /borderless /fullscreen in the game's Steam command line. Despite its fairly poor optimisation and forced online, this game took Just Cause 2 and improved on many of that game's aspects, especially in terms of visuals and game mechanics (most notably the wingsuit), and as such, it's a fun title to play around with for a while. Yet gameplay outside the story quickly becomes repetitive and lacklustre, and the flawed Rebel Drop system severely limits the player from creativity, particularly early-game. As such, this game is only worth the price when on sale, and Just Cause 2 will undoubtedly give more entertainment in the long-term - for a much lower price.Rating:1 - A masterpiece. An essential purchase for everyone.2 - Great game. Highly recommended to most people.3 - Fairly good game. Recommended mainly for fans of the genre or when on sale.4 - Poor game. Not recommended but has a few merits.5 - Awful game. Would not recommend to anyone in their right minds.

content:
Posted: December 4, 2015
												Well worth the wait, well worth the money!I had purchased this all the way back to May, after spending continuous weeks on JC2. This one is just as good, with better and worse parts.Better than JC2:+Graphics. Not perfect, but great. Could be better? Yes. Would that be necessary? No. Its good enough. It's great. I liked the optimization too. Worked almost fluent in all very high settings on my GTX860M Acer Nitro (Most people are having optimization and performance issues though).+The wingsuit. Ah, what a pleasure. I hope they consider putting this to JC2 as a mod. It changes the whole game.+Physics engine and the new wire tethering. With just a little experience, the need for guns is gone. And it doesn't get boring that fast. Very fun to play with.+Environments. With better graphics, better views. +New capturing system. No more "just kill everything". Still, these are just to keep things from being the same thing over and over again, for a while.+Loading times. The game loads while you watch the intros. And it does not take a very long time too. But you WILL need an SSD to stop nagging about it. Worse than JC2:-Controls. The steering delay is even worse, gun controls were better IMO.-Staying online all the time. Not mandatory, but keeps trying to compare achievements and annoys at times.-HUD. Minimap is gone, so are most of the object indicators.-Cutscenes are choppy. But, then again, it might just be my configuration.-Map and menu. They found a way to make the map even less functional, and more important.-Random glitches and crashes. Everyone's having different problems. Most people have performance issues too.Now, JC3 is great. It might suck where JC2 made its fame (optimization, controls) but it's still a lot fun to play. If you have not tried JC2, I suggest you give it a try first. They are basically the same.I can't help feeling that Just Cause 3 is an unfinished game. It feels like they had a couple more things to add but they reached the deadline. It could be better, eventhough it's already worth the money.

content:

												Ridiculously broken at the moment for me, (R9 270X & Athlon 750K  8GB RAM) but tuns at a decent framerate. Only like half the worlds polygons load in.But I've played 10+ hrs like that and enjoyed all of it so it's quite good to me. It's essentially and updated JC2, more refined and some cool new things added.I reccomend the game, assuming that AMD/Avalanche get it together and patch the issues.12/20/15:Both AMD and avalanche released patches, and the game functions normally now, runs pretty well on my rig with settings somwhere between medium and high. Loading times are not so great for me however, I have the game stored on a 7200 RPM SATA drive, and I usually have to load for about a minute for everything, except the initial startup, which is more like 4 minutes. Not a huge deal, but it seems like the kind of problem an older game would have.Just beat the story and liberated everything, except for 3 settlements that I can't find, and don't seem to belong to a province.I can say I enjoyed the game, and I would reccomend it, however for 60$, I don't feel the content is diverse enough for the price. Each town you liberate is pretty much the same, there are a few types of military bases, but not many. There are so many of these that it kind of becomes a chore, and more so once you figure out how to destroy stuff the easiest.Another issue; in JC2, my favorite part was foing to and from missions, which isn't the case in this game, because my favorite way to get around was by eingsuit and fast travel, since the driving physics were bizzare to me. While you're in the air, the only things that makes traveling interesting are trees and mountains. By interesting I mostly mean difficult. As a whole however, I quite liked wingsuiting around Medici.As many people talked about around release time, the game world is huge, but the content is just spread out, making it somewhat artificially large. This doesn't bother me a whole lot, considering it's more reason to use the wingsuit, but it was something that I definately noticed throughout the game. Story is aggressively mediocre, but it didn't bother me at all. Everything is cheesy and over the top, whih is fun, but don't expect anything to wow you or interest you greatly.Graphics are fanastic, possibly the nicest looking game I've played, considering not jsut textures and polygons, but colors and art. Very pretty game.Overall I'd give it a hearty recomendation if you're willing to grind through liberatiing everything, and if you don't mind a cheesy story.

More distinctly than the previous game, the characters are much better defined and far more interesting.- Navigation: Holy damn, the wingsuit is fantastic. That, combined with your parachute, fast travel, and vehicles everywhere, getting around is a breeze and loads of fun.- Weaponry: Easy choice here, it's chaos on a massive scale, and it's balls-to-the-wall fun with tons of options.- Scenery: Medici is a beautiful place. Even on only "high" settings, it's a well-designed place with towns that feel alive and countryside perfectly populated to feel realistic.CONS:- Performance: As is everyone else's complaints, I've noticed it also. Even scaling down to "high" settings, there are occassional dips in FPS, especially with destruction.- Bugs: There are a few bugs with weaponry and planes, one in particular that prevents campaign completion (heat seeking doesn't working in "Rico and the Rose").- Police Stations: Claiming most is fine, usually simple. But the "destroy X PLUS cause chaos" leads to a few terribly stupid situations where you're waiting for reinforcements one by one to kill enough crap to conquer it. Dumb mechanic.- Vehicles: Most are useless, honestly. Motorcycles especially drive like absolute garbage. Most cars/boats don't get much use, you just end up find the most useful tanks/fighters/combat boats and using those. Fun for collecting and messing around, at best.Honestly, given its scope, there's not too much about the gameplay I have complaints about. It's unadulterated chaos in a beautiful open world. Definitely recommend it.

Posted: March 11, 2016
 One step forward, two steps back Before I begin my review I'd like to add some context - Just Cause 2 was one of the first games I've played when I got my own pc back in 2011. It was a very enjoyable open world game that defined the current generation of sandbox games. So when Just Cause 3 was announced last year, I was genuinely hyped. Even though these days you can't get hyped about a game without worrying about how it'll perform on launch day, I didn't care, because Just Cause 2 was a very optimized game and Square Enix has a decent record of games with good optimization. That being said, I was getting ever and ever more doubtful, how the pre-release coverage of the game showed so little as opposed to other AAA titles, how no one was talking about the map, performance or anything. Hell the biggest feature of this franchise, the map, was shown only a week eariler before release. And when it did release, I couldn't play the game because of the horrible optimization. That being said, after a few patches and buying more RAM, I finally got to play it. Now on to the review. GRAPHICS The graphics in this game speaks for itself. You can see farmlands, sunflower fields and scattered villages for miles. The spires of big bases have a very significant apperance of Di Ravello's oppresive regime. Beautiful sea beaches merge with coves and scattered cliffsides. At night the cities and bases light up and provide a beacon for it be discovered.  SOUND This game is a treat for the ear as much as the eye - guns sound powerful, sports cars sound ferociously fast and explosions give that great sound of satisfaction that you may not find in any other game.  MAP & GAMEPLAY Now on to the part which I found most controversial. The map of Just Cause 3 seems much more lackluster compared to JC2. There aren't any more landmark locations like the Mile High Club, the Radar Dish, or the Radio Tower. Instead there's just a lot of villages and bases. Sure they look unique from each other, but it's a step back from JC2. Also half of the biggest island is literally walled off and abandoned, where in a similar way in JC2 there were  a lot more villages, bases etc. Roads look like masking tapes put on the floor, the highways have no hoardings above them, there are no dividers and the biggest city - citate di ravello, is as lack luster as it can get. The gameplay is a bit cumbersome. Auto aiming is gone, so expect a lot missed shots. The health meter is gone, though now it's the same as not getting health pack like in JC2. The minimap is gone, so you won't know where are the enemies and you won't notice the remaining chaos objects without pausing the game and looking up on the map.Sure they changed the driving model, cars tend not to swivel out of control, but bikes on the other hand will behave realistically and just won't go straight. I wish  the Sleeping Dog's driving model was implemented here. The biggest change this game offers is the wingsuit and in the sky fortress dlc, it turns into a ♥♥♥♥ing jetpack. Though it's quite fun. It is only one step forward from the last game.  FINAL VERDICT Just Cause 3 behaves similarly to Just Cause 2,the map has been stripped to just bases and cities. As if the developers played a lot of Far Cry 3 and added it's wingsuit and nothing much else. There is much more accesibility, and the game is still jolly good fun. I'd recommend buying now. Because once this goes on sale, it'll just be another $5 game that you'll never play , another entry in your untouched game library.

												This game is an improvement to Just Cause 2 in every way. I'm not sure why the "gaming community" is so torn between it. Take Just Cause 2 and compare it to this one, because thats all it is, a sequel to a good game. The shooting part of the game actually works well, and you don't run out of bullets every 5 seconds running around looking for another gun, nor do you go through a whole clip trying to take down on person.The vehicles control like....vehicles? rather than little boxes that flip and go flying at every little bump in the road. The controls feel more realistic than the last game.I have seen people complaining about the story of this game. Why don't you load up a fresh game of JC2 and try to tell me the intro to that game isn't the worst piece of writing ever? I love the way the grapple hook works now, along with a wingsuit. Put that in with the first DLC that gives you a jet pack, gun and rocket launcher attached to the wingsuit, its the best addition to the series yet. My favorite complaint I have read on several reviews is that liberating towns is repetitive and boring. Did we not play the same game? Because thats exactly what you did in JC2, run around blowing everything up in a town or military base until you had control over it. The only difference now is that you aren't looking for crates of weapons, you're raising a flagI have also read about the "long" load times and long connection to get online. This is 2016, and a Q4 2015 game. Maybe consider buying an SSD and get with current gen hardware before complaining about long load times. Takes no time to load this game on my SSD.I'm even impressed with the graphics with what it requires, and doesn't. By that I mean the system requirements are higher than my system in certain aspects. Running an i5 3570K with 8 GB RAM and an Nvidia GTX 660. The recommended system req. are higher, however I have been running this game on max settings for 2 days now, flown around everywhere and tried lagging the game out with massive explosions, with no problems. I would highly recommend this game to anyone who wants a game thats just about explosions and pure enjoyment, because that's what this game is. You run around and blow things up, this isn't a cure for cancer, and it isnt the second coming of christ. Try to remember this is a sequel to Just Cause 2. This isn't GTA, or JC2 Online where you boost around everywhere at 1000 MPH and have unlimited everything, and you too might one day be able to make your own opinion instead of mindlessly following others.

												If it's >=75% off, you have the money to spend and really enjoy Just Cause, sure.I bought this game during the Christmas sale at 20% off ($47.99 US) and have enjoyed my purchase, though I wish I'd waited for a deeper sale.PROS: - It's really fun in freeroam- The story is the best out of the series (e.g. terrible but enjoyable campy)- Avalanche knows the strengths of the series, so you're powerful but so is the AI- The wingsuit is a great addition- Nuke launcher- Tanks and helicopters with shields- It's amazing how good it is considering the ♥♥♥♥♥♥ business practices- Great graphics, nice aesthetic- Plenty of easter eggs- Amazing explosionsNEUTRAL: - A lot of weapons are gated behind missions- Acceptable performance: Was above 50 fps 99% of the time, which is good for me, on a 980 (keep in mind my monitor is connected via HDMI so it's locked to 60) with every setting except AA maxed. Did see some stuttering in high-foliage environments like forests, but that's expected for me. CONS: - One save slot. On PC. Really.- ♥♥♥♥♥♥ always-online DRM (ironic because the enemy is called the DRM)- Most side missions to unlock gear mods are super boring*- Enemies can be bullet sponges- Buggy**- Moderately high pop-in- The volcano in the game does not have a base inside it- Load times in the 5-10 minute range, thanks to the before-mentioned always-online DRM- Once you complete the game, you must manually "re-oppress" every base seperately. And you need to teleport to that base to do it, which can take upwards of 30 seconds. Don't expect to easily have a new game plus run without save editing.*The wingsuit courses are fun, the gun range is super easy if you have a mouse, the rest are just annoying because you almost get x stars but are just off**I've noticed at least four bugs:-If you go at high enough velocity downwards, you go through the ground and have to swim to the coast, underground- Helicopters can instantly die if their rotors clip something because the rotors apparently have the mass of the whole helicopter- If you have precision aim (which is an unlockable upgrade, for some reason) on, missiles don't lock on. A patch tried to fix this, but it's still broken for me. This means you can't complete certain missions without restarting the game.- A ♥♥♥♥ton of flickeringNOTESThere's ~5-10 minutes of loading before starting the game. Probably an hour or two of my 'playtime' was loading, especially considering it sometimes didn't connect and so reconnected everytime I paused or opened a menu. This is in service of a leaderboard which is interesting but which doesn't justify the connection times or lack of an offline mode. You can physically unplug your internet or disconnect your computer, but it still attempts connection on every loading screen, even if you're offline on Steam. It's a testament to this game that I was able to still enjoy and recommend it. Also, I played it with the default version which did not include any DLC and I beat the campaign and liberated every base in 36 hours, which included significant ♥♥♥♥ing around.

												I'm going to say it straight foward, this game is incredible if you have the rig to run it.People are knocking this game because of its inferior performance to games like GTAV and MGSV, which are slower paced games. This game moves fast, and your game will move slow if your computer is slow a snail.  So if you have a sub-par computer that does not meet the recommended requirements. Put this game in the wish list, becuase it is damn well worth it when you have a rig that can properly run it  (My GTX 960 and Haswell I7 run it at a crystal clear 60fps with ultra settings (AA at MSAA 4x)). Is this game perfect? No, it is not perfect. The main story is not the crux of the show, it comes in the form of the town clearing and the challenges. This game shoots itself in the foot by hampering a ridiculous amount of your power through the upgrade system, so while you are playing the game, do the challenges. No, you might not get 5 stars initially, but the upgrades are worth the effort. When you have even semi-maxed tethers and grenades, the♥♥♥♥♥♥you can do is so much fun that it's worth it.I do have to say that the wingsuit was the most frustrating part for me in terms of challenges. Not because of the variety and beautiful vistas that they take you through, but because of how poorly the wingsuit handled for me initially. Unfortunately, I have only a mouse and keyboard, but you can actually master the wingsuit with mouse and keyboard. If you tap the keys rapidly to do your maneuvers, you won't have your movement locked and faceplant into the ground. Just a piece of advice from me to you.To those who say the DLC is too short, I understand where you're coming from, but do not forget that the idea is to combine them and use them in the main game. And holy♥♥♥♥♥♥ it is really fun to go through Montagne and the mines with the DLC content. I would suggest playing through the vanilla content by itself initially, but the DLC content provided me an extra 25 hours of gameplay just by screwing around with the weapons that the DLC provide. Did I mention that the OST is amazing? The game feels so great with headphones while you blowing people to shreds. The game's appeal is not from using amazing gadgets, this is not your average Ubisoft open-world. It is a crazy game that will  NOT  hold your hand at baby dumb mode. You can't move around and kill easily on foot? No♥♥♥♥♥♥ the name of the game is to fly around and blow♥♥♥♥♥♥up from the skies with your parachute and gadgets. You can beat the game by simply hitting♥♥♥♥♥♥with the gun on ground, but this is a classic Eidos game. There's more depth to it that you expect.It took me 95 hours to 100% this game over winter break, and it was one of the greatest times I've ever had with a game. If you have the rig to run it and the patience to get good at it, you will not regret it at all.

content:
Posted: May 22, 2016
												Feel free to liberate towns by blowing up statues and loudspeakers, assault military bases by exploding everything inside, or just goof around by making your chosen thing go boom. The developer has improved how escalation works in these scenarios, no longer lurching from single policeman to tanks the moment you’re spotted. For the first time, hiding is a viable tactic to lose heat, and a pleasant innovation allows you to spot somebody calling for backup and take them out accordingly. If things get too hairy you can even find sanctuary with a priest to reset the wanted counter to zero.The surroundings are so exquisite that sometimes it’s worth enduring the slideshow for the canapes and champagne. This is a sumptuous world teeming with stuff to do. The scripted campaign isn’t perfect but there are entertaining set pieces and I recommend doing at least the first few to gain essentials like supply drops and fast travel. It’s also worth taking on challenges like car races and wingsuit courses to obtain upgrades; you can compete against ghosts of your friends as an added incentive.Just Cause is a beautiful playground that allows you to star in your own totally ridiculous action film. It may lack depth but it’s hard to care when you’re grappling out of a crashing helicopter into the cockpit of a Formula One car. However, you definitely will care if your driving style is more Pastor Maldonado than Lewis Hamilton because the frame rate has slowed to a crawl. Hopefully patches will smooth everything out, but until then a potentially great game comes recommended.There are some known issues that occur with the most recent official release AMD/ATi graphics card drivers.Just Cause 3 already has several patches, but not everything is fixed yet.

content:
Posted: July 20, 2016
												Why should you buy this game. Just Cause. Ok got that out of the way. Just Cause 3 is a open-world sandbox psychopath simulator where you fill the nitroglicerin filled shoes of Rico Rodrigez: professional dictator remover. No really that's his job title. Just Cause 3 is all about exploring a very beatiful series of islands and liberating them from a powerhungry despot by blowing them to oblivion. Liberate! The core gameplay revolves entirely around blowing stuff up and doing it with style. The entire sandbox is built around that design system and if you are looking for a more story driven experience then you better continue looking because this isn't your game. With that said I have adress the elephant in the room: that game has some notable technical issues that have made the game borderline unplayable for some people. I can run it pretty well on medium settings with some framerate drops when I'm blowing a military base into the stratosphere but so far there hasn't been any outright gamebreaking framedrops (My laptop uses a Nvidia 780M and I have 32GB of RAM). With that said if you don't have a decent video card and at least 12 GB of RAM I'd suggest holding off buying JC3. But if you have required specs the you should go for it.

content:
Posted: March 3, 2016
												I just completed the game with 100% province and story completion, so my opinion in light of that:The Good: This is a spectacle shooter. If you like explosions, Rambo-like action, think 80s shooter movie, then you'll enjoy that aspect. The graphics are much better than Just Cause 2, and there are a few (not many) tweaks and changes made to your arsenal to open up some possiblities.The Bad: This isn't much of an evolution from Just Cause 2. It isn't worth $60, although it held my attention for 25+ hours, I do think it is a solid pick in the $30-$40 range, but I'd wait for a Steam Sale.The story is by-the-numbers, and there isn't much in the way of depth. Not much changed from the first province taken to the last. By the end I was just tired and wanting to complete it. The best part of the game is the voice acting of the Medici radio announcer, which is no surprise since I'm a Doctor Who fan. I was more concerned about his fate than the rest of the story. In any event, pick it up on a sale and if you go in with low expectations you'll have a great time. If there were a star rating, I'd give it a 3/5.

												I had no issues running this on my rig (GTX 1060 6GB, Intel Core i5 6500, 8GB of ram). The gameplay is improved over JC2 through many minor tweaks to various aspects. It feels less clunky and less restrictive than the previous game. The story is still pretty weak and predictable. The upgrade system is nice however the challenges are pretty meh. The way to unlock more abilities and thus improve your character is to succeed at random minigames dispersed throughout the map with no context. These challenges tend to be like fun little arcade games but they can get repetitive and occasionally frustrating. I personally dislike how far removed these things are from the rest of the game. Driving a car through hoops really fast doesn't feel at all connected to the goal of removing a dictatorship. I would still recommend this game because the open world feels like a better Just Cause 2 and it is fun to mess around with the civilians. I'd say pick it up when it's at $15 if you have a solid computer and enjoyed Just Cause 2.
